headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Linear Technology Corporation Fiscal 2016 Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Don Zerio, Vice President of Finance and Chief
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Linear Technology Corporation Fiscal 2016 Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Don Zerio, Vice President of Finance and Chief Financial Officer. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Welcome to the Linear Technology conference call. I am joined today by Bob Swanson, our Executive Chairman; and Lothar Maier, our CEO. Firstly, I would like to mention that we are hosting this call from Hong Kong, where it is 12:30 A.M. We i
componenttext:
Good morning. Welcome to the Linear Technology conference call. I am joined today by Bob Swanson, our Executive Chairman; and Lothar Maier, our CEO. Firstly, I would like to mention that we are hosting this call from Hong Kong, where it is 12:30 A.M. We intend to keep my opening comments brief, and hopefully, you will cut us some slack during the Q&A given the late hour. Secondly, I would like to remind you that in our presentation today and our answers to certain questions that may follow, we may make forward-looking statements that are dependent on certain risks and uncertainties, including, but not limited to, our financial results for future periods; our ability to produce and sell existing products; the timely introduction of new products and processes and general conditions in the world economy and financial markets. In addition to these risks, please refer to the risk factors listed in the company's annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended June 28, 2015. Also, SEC Regulation FD regarding selective disclosure influences our interaction with investors. Accordingly, this conference call will be our forum to respond to questions regarding our estimated financial performance going forward. Should you have questions regarding our estimates of sales and profits or other financial matters for the upcoming quarter, this is the time we are free to respond to your questions. 
As noted on our press release which was released yesterday just after the market closed, revenue for the December quarter came in at the midpoint of our guidance at $347.1 million, up 1.5% from the September quarter. Due to higher sales, more production days and related manufacturing efficiencies, gross margin increased from 75.1% to 75.7%. Operating income was affected by the extra week this quarter as the extra week added higher operating expenses, primarily in labor-related costs, including stock compensation and certain other operational costs increase as well. Just to clarify, fiscal 2016 is a fiscal 53-week year, and we add that week to the December quarter, making it a 14-week quarter versus the typical 13 weeks. As a result of the added expenses, operating income dropped to 43.1% of sales versus 43.8% last quarter. Net income received a benefit from the lower tax rate of 19.5% compared to 25.75% in Q1 due to the permanent reinstatement of the R&D tax credit. Net income and earnings per share were $121.5 million and $0.50, of which $0.04 was due to the lower tax rate. 
For the 24th conservative year since the company began paying a dividend, the Board of Directors has once again approved a dividend increase, making the dividend $0.02 to $0.32 per share payable on February 24, 2016. Recent history shows that the December quarter is usually a down quarter for us in part due to seasonality. We are pleased that we have showed sequential growth in a difficult environment. Yes, we had an extra week [indiscernible] quarter revenue, but as I indicated last quarter, the calendar year and timing of that extra week typically does not translate into much additional revenue. That, in fact, turned out to be true. It is difficult to say exactly what that amount was due to year-end shipment patterns and the lack of full visibility of third party POS data, but we believe it was not much at all, if any, under direct OEM business, and is definitely less than 2 extra days on average I estimated might be from distribution. While I can't say for certain how much it was so I won't guess and I'll let you make your own estimate. Bookings on the other hand, are easier to quantify, and they did pick up at the end of the month. Unlike sales, we did get about 3 additional days of bookings on average from the extra week, which is more than we expected for that period. In the early part of the current quarter, bookings per day have improved over the December quarter and a positive book-to-bill ratio has given us some extra backlog heading into the March quarter. That gives us reason for optimism. As the macroeconomic picture is no better than last quarter if it is not worse, and all we have to do is read the paper and check the markets to know that. 
Naturally there's a lot of caution other among our customers. In light of all this, we are currently projecting revenue to be up 2% to 5% in the March quarter. This forecast assumes that the current run rate for bookings does not slow considerably, and that the industrial market continues to improve from the recent lull we saw in September. These are not assumptions that can be guaranteed in the current economic climate. 
Turning to bookings by region and market sector, as a reminder, we have posted bookings by market and revenue by geography for the quarter on our website at linear.com. Just click Company, Investor Relations and Supplemental Information. We post this information by the end of our business day on the day we released our results. Total bookings increased for the quarter, and we had a positive book-to-bill ratio. Bookings increased in both North America and the international market. Within international, bookings were up in Europe and Asia Pacific but were down in Japan. Despite the relative turmoil in the China market, it continues to be a bright spot as bookings were up the most in that geographic region on the strength of automotive. With respect to bookings by market sector, our 3 biggest markets, industrial, transportation and communications, were all up modestly led by transportation in both dollars and as a percentage. Of our smaller markets, military space was up following the weak September quarter, while computer and consumer were both down. The computer market, particularly PCs and notebooks, continue to be particularly weak, and we are certainly not alone in feeling that. 
Industrial continues to be our largest market at 43% of our bookings, the same as the previous quarter, but we did see some improvement in bookings as we hoped coming off a weak Q1. The increase in bookings was led by North America followed by Asia Pacific and Europe. Japan was essentially flat. We are encouraged by the increase as a whole, but we would not yet characterize it as a sign of strength as we're still a ways from the bookings we've had a year or so ago. So we characterized it as less weak and I think that is a good way to put it right now. March is historically a stronger industrial quarter, so this quarter should shed some better light. The overall increase in bookings was led by transportation, which increased to 23% of our business up from 22%. The increase in bookings in transportation was driven primarily by Asia Pacific, and to a lesser extent, Europe, while North America was flat and Japan was down. Asia Pacific is showing continued strength from China due in large part to the success of our battery management products for hybrid and electric vehicles. China is currently offering significant incentives to both businesses and consumers to build and buy electric, and our BMS products have helped us capitalize on that. Korea is also a good transportation market for us as well in Asia Pacific. 
Bookings in the communications market increased as North America bookings bounced back a bit from a weak first quarter. Europe and Asia were up as well, but just slightly, and Japan was flat. Communications remained at 18% of our bookings for the quarter. 
The computer market was 7% of our market, down from 9% last quarter with the decrease primarily in North America, where the majority of this business is booked. As stated previously, this market is suffering due to weaker notebook sales, and to a lesser extent, stores devices such as solid state drives. This market may continue to [indiscernible] a bit for us over in the short term as notebook sales continue to decline as expected. Longer term, we are still very much in this market and expect growth opportunities to come to fruition as we have products that address the high end of this market. 
Bookings for military, space and harsh environment products were higher this quarter, pushing its share back to 6% of our business, as has been the norm. Military bounced back from a weak first quarter, while the space business have been somewhat flat for the past year. We do expect the space business to improve as satellite launch activity picks up. This is predominantly a U.S. market, though we do book some business in Europe. 
Finally, consumer, our smallest end market and one we don't focus on, remained at 3% of our bookings though bookings were down in the quarter. With regard to where our bookings are actually created, 62% were created internationally, and 38% in North America versus 61% and 39% respectively last period. 
Moving on to sales, sales increased by 1.5% from the prior quarter and were down 1.5% from the prior year quarter. Geographically, sales were up in both North America and Rest of World, which is primarily Asia Pacific. Europe was essentially flat, while Japan was down. On a regional basis, North America was 27% of our business compared to 28% last quarter. Europe and Japan each remained at 19% [ph] and 15%, respectively. Asia Pacific increased from 38% of sales to 39%. 
Turning to the rest of the income statement, gross margin was up from 75.1% to 75.7%. This is a relatively large increase on a modest sales increase, and it is unusual that cost of sales is actually less in dollars than the September quarter on higher sales volume. This results from several factors. Firstly, and obviously, the higher sales base allows us to spread factory overhead over more units sold. Secondly, gross margin in the prior quarter fell an entire point about the sharp downturn in revenue and our manufacturing plants were relatively inefficient from the quick and sudden drop in production. This turnaround to some extent during the current quarter as production stabilized. Also, despite a one week closure during the holiday week, we have 4 more production days on average, netting the shutdown days we had in each quarter. We also had an improvement in our average selling price to $0.04 to $1.92. Finally, we had some improvement due to foreign exchange, particularly, the Malaysian ringgit, lowering the cost of our foreign plants. Overall, that nets us to a very nice gross margin under the circumstances, with more than expected from the modest increase in sales. I do not expect a similar improvement in gross margin next quarter as we will lose some of those manufacturing efficiencies with our back end plants in Penang in Singapore closing for Chinese New Year, so I don't expect a decline either. 
R&D increased $3.3 million sequentially to $69.1 million, primarily due to higher labor cost and stock compensation from the one extra week in the quarter. In addition, legal costs were up slightly as were other costs such as supplies, small equipment, travel and entertainment. SG&A increased $3.2 million sequentially to $43.4 million, also due to the higher labor costs and stock compensation from 1 extra week in the quarter. In addition, other costs increased primarily for advertising and travel. Due to the extra week in the quarter and the holiday period that included shutdown days for employees, this was an unusual quarter for operating expenses. So our operating expense ratio at 32.2% is unusually high. Just like revenue, it is difficult to say for sure what the extra week was were, net of the impact of the days that we shut down. As I believe you are more concerned about what the expenses would be going forward, I expect that our operating expenses with modest improvement in sales to be more in line with our first quarter in the 31% range, if not better. One thing to remember, this non-cash stock compensation is rising faster than our cash expenses as older, lower price grants best and are replaced by new higher priced grants. Recently though, it appears that the stock market is trying to take care of that difference. 
Operating income declined slightly by $0.5 million to $149.5 million, representing 43.1% of sales, again, impacted by the extra week in the quarter. And just another income increased $500,000 to $1.5 million. Interest income was up about $300,000 due to a slightly higher investment yield. Other income included a $200,000 foreign-exchange gain on certain foreign currencies held. 
Our quarterly effective income tax rate was significantly lower this quarter at 19.5% versus 25.75% last quarter entirely due to the reinstatement of the R&D tax credit. Next quarter, absent discrete tax items, if any, we expect our annual effective tax rate to be in the 24% to 24.5% range. Net income for the period was $121.5 million, up $9.5 million and was 35% of sales, up from 32.8%. 
The average year outstanding used in the calculation of earnings per share increased by 232,000 shares. The weighted average stock repurchases both this period and last period was an offset increases from stock option exercises, investing of employee restricted stock awards. GAAP earnings per share was $0.50, up from $0.46 in the prior quarter. Without the impact of stock-based compensation of $20.3 million, which includes an extra week of stock-based compensation expense, diluted EPS would have been $0.56 [ph] per share. 
Given the late hour here, I'm going to skip the balance sheet commentary. I'm sure there are many of you who are not disappointed by that. 
Looking forward, using the data points we have at this time, from our customers and sales force, and relying somewhat on history that suggests the weakened so market will continue to rebound from the seasonally lower December quarter, we are guiding revenue to be up 2% to 5% sequentially in our third quarter. In the early part of this quarter, we are seeing recovery from certain geographies and certain customers. Also, the oversupply condition that occurred from the drop in demand 2 to 3 quarters ago have been mostly corrected. We believe in general oversupply is no longer a key issue for us for our OEM customers or in the distribution channel. We are seeing signs of life, but the macroeconomic climate is still fragile, so we're not calling the down cycle that began a few quarters ago over just yet. 
I would now like to open up the conference call to questions to be addressed by Bob, Lothar or me.

componenttext: Pretty solid execution given the macro environment out there. My first question is on the guide. Is the right way to think about it is you were shipping below demand in the quarter before December. So in December, you sort of caught up to that, and now you're guiding for a quarter. It seems to be more in line with seasonality. Is that the right way to think that now that you are shipping mostly in sync with the demand? And then I had a quick follow-up.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016

componenttext: Yes, I think that's correct.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016

componenttext: Okay, and then my follow-up is on the geographical side. You mentioned that China was strong in automotives. What is your read outside of the automotive market?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, China is also a good industrial market for us. And actually, the market as you know has been relatively weak. We are seeing signs of pickup. But China has been holding its own in industrial. So that's growing as well. So you're right that transporta
componenttext: Well, China is also a good industrial market for us. And actually, the market as you know has been relatively weak. We are seeing signs of pickup. But China has been holding its own in industrial. So that's growing as well. So you're right that transportation is growing stronger, but industrial market is doing just fine in China.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we will now take a question from Craig Hettenbach from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we will now take a question from Craig Hettenbach from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just following up on the China commentary, certainly there's been some stimulus on the automotive side. Just wanted to get a sense from you, as you kind of went through the quarter, just your view on the sustainability of the strength in China autos.
componenttext: Just following up on the China commentary, certainly there's been some stimulus on the automotive side. Just wanted to get a sense from you, as you kind of went through the quarter, just your view on the sustainability of the strength in China autos.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the strength in the China auto business is just beginning. I mean, based on what we're seeing and based on the amount of stimulus the Chinese government is putting in place, I think we're kind of on the early stages of -- it could be a pretty good
componenttext: I think the strength in the China auto business is just beginning. I mean, based on what we're seeing and based on the amount of stimulus the Chinese government is putting in place, I think we're kind of on the early stages of -- it could be a pretty good piece of business for us. We've done very well in the BMS portion of the Chinese automotive market. And as I say, the transportation, because it's not just cars, it's buses and taxis and vehicles as well. But and it's not just BMS. If you win the BMS business in a car, you're likely to win the other sockets as well. So I think we're kind of just in the early stages of this opportunity here in transportation in China.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And just as a follow-up, just staying with automotives, China kind of stands out. But your concerns around North American market. Anything else more broadly on a global basis that you're seeing in automotive?
componenttext: Got it. And just as a follow-up, just staying with automotives, China kind of stands out. But your concerns around North American market. Anything else more broadly on a global basis that you're seeing in automotive?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's just the amount of electronics that's going into cars. So there may be some either regional or global softness in vehicle sales but I don't think that's going to really deter the amount of electronics that goes in the cars. We spend a lot of time tal
componenttext: It's just the amount of electronics that's going into cars. So there may be some either regional or global softness in vehicle sales but I don't think that's going to really deter the amount of electronics that goes in the cars. We spend a lot of time talking about BMS, but we've got opportunities in many other applications in the cars. There's this always ADAS stuff that people are talking about. That's just beginning. And from our perspective, we see virtually every car manufacturer having some program that deals with this ADAS. And I'm not going to say that cars are going to be driving themselves here in the next year or  2 completely by themselves. There's just a lot of steppingstones to get to that point, and we are seeing those steppingstones happening right now.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Tore Svanberg from Stifel.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Tore Svanberg from Stifel.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question, the Japan business was weak and it looks like bookings remained weak. Is there anything structural going on there, or is this simply perhaps due to their strong currency?
componenttext: First question, the Japan business was weak and it looks like bookings remained weak. Is there anything structural going on there, or is this simply perhaps due to their strong currency?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's an interesting question because we know as well that Japan, actually a little weaker than maybe some of the other regions right now, and I think there's some economic reasons at Japan. But I think they're being affected by more than some ot
componenttext: I think that's an interesting question because we know as well that Japan, actually a little weaker than maybe some of the other regions right now, and I think there's some economic reasons at Japan. But I think they're being affected by more than some other regions by what's going on in China. The imports into China are probably slowing and the consumption is more domestic, and I think Japan is feeling that. On the bookings side, bookings going to the March quarter, March is the fiscal year end for most Japanese companies. So you get the typical sort of pushouts for shipment as they want to dress up their balance sheet a little bit. That's sort of normal seasonality. But it's more than that for sure. We think that China has something to do with it.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Don, in your prepared comments, you talked about sort of daily booking trends being better thus far through January than they were in December and what year in the December quarter improved. I'm kind of curious, is that typical? And can you help me unders
componenttext: Don, in your prepared comments, you talked about sort of daily booking trends being better thus far through January than they were in December and what year in the December quarter improved. I'm kind of curious, is that typical? And can you help me understand sort of normal linearity in the March quarter, especially given Chinese new year is in February this year?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chinese New Year, every year we have counted, it's not always the same week. So to be honest, we don't get the same pattern every year. Sometimes you get some strength going into Chinese New Year, and then maybe a little bit weakness afterwards. Sometimes
componenttext: Chinese New Year, every year we have counted, it's not always the same week. So to be honest, we don't get the same pattern every year. Sometimes you get some strength going into Chinese New Year, and then maybe a little bit weakness afterwards. Sometimes you get a little bit of weakness before and strength afterwards. So it's not always the same pattern, but as you know, the March quarter overall is a stronger industrial quarter for us. So I think just on average, taken out sort of the macroeconomics of it all, you would generally, see bookings accelerate somewhat through the quarter. But again, these are not normal times.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful, and then either for Don or for Lothar, industrial is such a large sort of umbrella bucket for all of the analog companies, yourself included. And I guess, one of the questions I'm getting is given that you are guiding to normal seasonal, r
componenttext: That's helpful, and then either for Don or for Lothar, industrial is such a large sort of umbrella bucket for all of the analog companies, yourself included. And I guess, one of the questions I'm getting is given that you are guiding to normal seasonal, roughly for the March quarter but still have kind of a cautious view on the macro, what are kind of some of the sub buckets within industrial that you guys worry about as being sort of the most macro-sensitive in an area where you could be caught by surprise if the macro remains weaker or gets weaker?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The industrial business for us is thousands of customers. So it's spread across a lot of markets. Obviously, medical is a portion of it that is doing, okay. If you ask me areas where I probably come from from industrial standpoint, worry about a little bi
componenttext: The industrial business for us is thousands of customers. So it's spread across a lot of markets. Obviously, medical is a portion of it that is doing, okay. If you ask me areas where I probably come from from industrial standpoint, worry about a little bit, we know that with the relatively low prices of petroleum right now, it's affecting some of our industrial customers who have business into the exploration markets. So I think we're going to see a little bit of softness on those. But I think overall, because the mix of customers and where the industrial products gets sold into, I think there's other factors that will probably balance that out. I mean, last quarter the industrial business and are actually pretty good even in the face of those headwinds.

componenttext: Could you give us some idea of roughly how much our automotive revenues rising year-over-year for you? And what do you expect going forward for automotive growth in 2016 or transportation?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, I think you know by now that we don't break out the dollars or the growth rates for each of our markets. And it would be a guess anyway. But I think what we have said is though you've seen a steady rise in our business of automotive from the teens,
componenttext: David, I think you know by now that we don't break out the dollars or the growth rates for each of our markets. And it would be a guess anyway. But I think what we have said is though you've seen a steady rise in our business of automotive from the teens, the 20%, the 21%, it's pretty much going up almost a point quarter-to-quarter. So we sort of see that continuing that automotive beginning to be more and more of our business. I mean, obviously, 25% is clearly within reach, and we wouldn't be surprised to see it go north from there.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm trying to reconcile your comments about the weak macro environment on one hand with 2 other things. First, your comments about improving bookings trends, and second, your one quarter out guidance and that while in line with normal seasonality, you're
componenttext: I'm trying to reconcile your comments about the weak macro environment on one hand with 2 other things. First, your comments about improving bookings trends, and second, your one quarter out guidance and that while in line with normal seasonality, you're coming off a 14-week quarter so it would appear to be better than what I would have expected on a seasonal basis. So can you help me sort of put those 2 together?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's a pretty good call, actually. I think you're right. We were able to still grow in a weak December quarter, but remember we came off from pretty weak quarter before that. So bookings, I would have to say, increased better-than-expected towar
componenttext: I think that's a pretty good call, actually. I think you're right. We were able to still grow in a weak December quarter, but remember we came off from pretty weak quarter before that. So bookings, I would have to say, increased better-than-expected towards the end of that December period. And they seized, they're looking pretty good right now. Definitely is a step increase over what we experienced throughout the entirety of the December quarter, but again, this is early in the quarter. There's no question's, still week out there. It's too early to say if the bookings will stay at that rate or even accelerate. John Pitzer asked before that based on history, we would expect that. But it's still early, early to say. But the optimism that we have is based on what you just said. It looked pretty good towards the end of the quarter and the beginning part of this quarter.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a follow-up if I can would be whether the bids this, would you be concerned that the better bookings rate you're seeing now that's leading to the quarter, in a sense, better than seasonal guidance can be a head fake if oil stays at the low $30 a barrel
componenttext: So a follow-up if I can would be whether the bids this, would you be concerned that the better bookings rate you're seeing now that's leading to the quarter, in a sense, better than seasonal guidance can be a head fake if oil stays at the low $30 a barrel that continues to pressure the whole sort of industrial complex.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a hard call to say, but if you ask me my opinion, my sense is that, that headwind we've already faced. We've had these relatively low prices for quite a while now, and I think most of the customers that have exposure to that market have probably re
componenttext: That's a hard call to say, but if you ask me my opinion, my sense is that, that headwind we've already faced. We've had these relatively low prices for quite a while now, and I think most of the customers that have exposure to that market have probably reacted are ready.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes., I guess, all I want to add was that although we're seeing strong bookings at the beginning of this year, at the beginning of this quarter. I mean, we are still bothered by the lack of any real good macroeconomic news. So I don't know if it's a head
componenttext: Yes., I guess, all I want to add was that although we're seeing strong bookings at the beginning of this year, at the beginning of this quarter. I mean, we are still bothered by the lack of any real good macroeconomic news. So I don't know if it's a head fake but we have to be mindful of that.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016

componenttext: And, if you kind of take a longer view, we'll price petroleum is probably in the long term, pretty good things. So even though there might be some near-term pain, I think long-term, this business is going to be a positive.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And will now take a question from Chris Caso from Susquehanna Financial Group.

I think it's less of some customers doing a great job or some market is doing well, I think we've picked the right markets and we've been at it now for quite a while. And we're seeing the benefits of it.

componenttext: Yes, as I stated, in the opening commentary, quite honestly, that to get a 60 base improvement, a little over $5 million increase in sales is unusual. So there is a lot of moving parts in there. So it's difficult to say going forward, which of those parts will continue. I do know for sure that there is a slight headwind if you call it that, just that we know we are closing down our back and factory so less production days mean some inefficiencies, less absorption so that affects us, the Chinese new year on Singapore and in Malaysia. But the ASP certainly helps and that's mixed. I can't say what just yet what mixes going to be in the current quarter. I will say that in fairness to our factories, it wasn't just number of production days, I mean, there's some real P&L improvement and some cost-saving effort that they've achieved but in terms of collar going forward. I do -- I don't expect another 60 base improvement in gross margin on the higher sales growth if we actually hit our target. So I'm a just cautious about saying that. I wouldn't expect even with the shutdown of our back and patch or for Chinese new year so I wouldn't expect it to decline. Hopefully, we'll get some improvement but it's so early to know. Just like you said, there's just a lot of moving pieces.

componenttext: I think I've answered this question before in the past. We're not going to say it has no effect. componenttext: You mentioned M&A. We're not a big player in that field and so in the past, we did a large transaction in 2007. When we felt our strategy was not well understood and that's when we're focusing more on automotive and industrial. We retired that debt a little over a year ago. We've been using our existing cash to retire shares, and we've done that, we brought back at least those that we've issued. That's sort of our secondary costs, if you will, behind this dividend. But in terms of something going forward, we'll just have to just wait and see.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Initially, when we started to see a pickup in the automotive business, it was really dominated by conventional gasoline-powered cars. That is starting to evolve and it's -- as more car OEMs field electric and hybrid and plug-in hybrid cars, even those tod
componenttext: Initially, when we started to see a pickup in the automotive business, it was really dominated by conventional gasoline-powered cars. That is starting to evolve and it's -- as more car OEMs field electric and hybrid and plug-in hybrid cars, even those today, the quantity of those cars are still relatively small, the content of opportunities for Linear are significantly higher, multiple tire in those types of cars. So the hybrid and electric vehicle market is a very interesting market for us because it has a much, much higher electronic content for us. So that's where we're seeing some pretty significant opportunities. But there's a sort of waves of new areas for electronics that are coming in the cars. I mentioned earlier the 48 whole battery system, that's going to have a wave of opportunities. ADAS systems is going to have a wave of opportunities. And we're just seeing these waves of opportunities coming in, and I think there's just a lot of good opportunities for vehicles right now and we've seen the benefit of it in the last several years where we've seen pretty steady growth in automotive sales, and also in the percentage of our sales that go into the automotive market. So I hope that answered a part of your question.

componenttextpreview: Good morning. Welcome to the Linear Technology conference call. I am joined today by Bob Swanson, our Executive Chairman; and Lothar Maier, our CEO. Firstly, I would like to mention that we are hosting this call from Hong Kong, where it is 12:30 A.M. So I
componenttext:
Good morning. Welcome to the Linear Technology conference call. I am joined today by Bob Swanson, our Executive Chairman; and Lothar Maier, our CEO. Firstly, I would like to mention that we are hosting this call from Hong Kong, where it is 12:30 A.M. So I intend to keep my opening comments brief, and hopefully, you will cut us some slack during the Q&A given the late hour. Secondly, I would like to remind you that in our presentation today and our answers to certain questions that may follow, we may make forward-looking statements that are dependent on certain risk and uncertainties, including, but not limited to, our financial results for future periods; our ability to produce and sell existing products; the timely introduction of new products and processes and general conditions in the world economy and financial markets. In addition to these risks, please refer to the risk factors listed in the company's annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended June 28, 2015. Also, SEC Regulation FD regarding selective disclosure influences our interaction with investors. Accordingly, this conference call will be our forum to respond to questions regarding our estimated financial performance going forward. Should you have questions regarding our estimates of sales and profits or other financial matters for the upcoming quarter, this is the time we are free to respond to your questions. 
As noted on press release, which was released yesterday just after the market closed, revenue for the December quarter came in at the midpoint of our guidance at $347.1 million, up 1.5% from the September quarter. Due to higher sales, more production days and related manufacturing efficiencies, gross margin increased from 75.1% to 75.7%. Operating income was affected by the extra week this quarter as the extra week added higher operating expenses, primarily in labor-related costs, including stock compensations and certain other operational cost increase as well. 
Just to clarify, fiscal 2016 is a fiscal 53-week year, and we add that week to the December quarter, making it a 14-week quarter versus the typical 13 weeks. As a result of the added expenses, operating income dropped to 43.1% of sales versus 43.8% last quarter. Net income received a benefit from a lower tax rate of 19.5% compared to 25.75% in Q1 due to the permanent reinstatement of the R&D tax credit. Net income and earnings per share were $121.5 million and $0.50, of which $0.04 was due to the lower tax rate. 
For the 24th conservative year since the company began paying a dividend, the Board of Directors has once again approved a dividend increase, raising the dividend $0.02 to $0.32 per share payable on February 24, 2016. Recent history shows that the December quarter is usually a down quarter for us in part due to seasonality. So we are pleased that we showed some sequential growth in a difficult economic environment. Yes, we had an extra week to record revenue, but as I indicated last quarter, the calendar year end timing of that extra week typically does not translate into much additional revenue. That, in fact, turned out to be true. 
It is difficult to say exactly what that amount was due to year-end shipment patterns and the lack of full visibility of third party POS data, but we believe it was not much at all, if any, on the direct OEM business, and it is definitely less than 2 extra days on average, I estimated it might be from distribution. While I can't say for certain how much it was so I won't guess and I'll let you make your own estimate. 
Bookings on the other hand, are easier to quantify, and they did pick up at the end of the month. Unlike sales, we did get about 3 additional days of bookings on average from the extra week, which is more than we expected for that period. In the early part of the current quarter, bookings per day have improved over the December quarter and a positive book-to-bill ratio has given us some extra backlog heading into the March quarter. That gives us reason for optimism. As the macroeconomic picture is no better than last quarter if it is not worse, and all we have to do is read the paper and check the markets to know that. 
Naturally there's a lot of caution out there among our customers. In light of all this, we are currently projecting revenue to be up 2% to 5% in the March quarter. This forecast assumes that the current run rate for bookings does not slow considerably, and that the industrial market continues to improve from the recent low we saw in the September quarter. These are not assumptions that can be guaranteed in the current economic climate. 
Turning to bookings by region and market sector, as a reminder, we have posted bookings by market and revenue by geography for the quarter on our website at linear.com. Just click Company, Investor Relations and Supplemental Information. We post this information by the end of our business day on the day we release our results. Total bookings increased for the quarter and we had a positive book-to-bill ratio. Bookings increased in both North America and the international market. Within international, bookings were up in Europe and Asia Pacific but were down in Japan. Despite the relative turmoil in the China market, it continues to be a bright spot as bookings were up the most in that geographic region on the strength of automotive. 
With respect to bookings by market sector, our 3 biggest markets, industrial, transportation and communications, were all up modestly led by transportation in both dollars and as a percentage. Of our smaller markets, military space was up following the weak September quarter, while computer and consumer were both down. The computer market, particularly PCs and notebooks, continue to be particularly weak, and we are certainly not alone in feeling that. 
Industrial continues to be our largest market at 43% of our bookings, the same as the previous quarter, but we did see some improvement in bookings as we hoped coming off a weak Q1. The increase in bookings was led by North America followed by Asia Pacific and Europe. Japan was essentially flat. We are encouraged by the increase as a whole, but we would not yet characterize it as a sign of strength as we're still a ways from the bookings that we've had a year or so ago. So when characterized it as less weak, and I think that is a good way to put it right now. 
March is historically a stronger industrial quarter, so this quarter should shed some better light. The overall increase in bookings was led by transportation, which increased to 23% of our business up from 22%. The increase in bookings in transportation was driven primarily by Asia Pacific, and to a lesser extent, Europe, while North America was flat and Japan was down. Asia Pacific is showing continued strength from China due in large part to the success of our battery management products for hybrid and electric vehicles. China is currently offering significant incentives to both businesses and consumers to build and buy electric, and our BMS products have helped us capitalize on that. Korea is also a good transportation market for us as well in Asia Pacific. 
Bookings in the communications market increased as North America bookings bounced back a bit from a weak first quarter. Europe and Asia were up as well, but just slightly, and Japan was flat. Communications remained at 18% of our bookings for the quarter. 
The computer market was 7% of our bookings, down from 9% last quarter with the decrease primarily in North America, where the majority of this business is booked. As stated previously, this market is suffering due to weaker notebook sales, and to a lesser extent, stores devices such as solid state drives. This market may continue to [indiscernible] a bit for us over the short term as notebook sales continue to decline as expected. Longer term, we are still very much in this market and expect growth opportunities to come to fruition as we have products that address the high end of this market. 
Bookings for military, space and harsh environment products were higher this quarter, pushing its share back to 6% of our business as has been the norm. Military bounced back from a weak first quarter, while the space business has been somewhat flat for the past year. We do expect the space business to improve as satellite launch activity picks up. This is predominantly a U.S. market, though we do book some business in Europe. 
Finally, consumer, our smallest end market and one we don't focus on, remained at 3% of our bookings though bookings were down in the quarter. With regard to where our bookings are actually created, 62% were created internationally, and 38% in North America versus 61% and 39% respectively last period. 
Moving on to sales, sales increased by 1.5% from the prior quarter and were down 1.5% from the prior year quarter. Geographically, sales were up in both North America and rest of world, which is primarily Asia Pacific. Europe was essentially flat, while Japan was down. On a regional basis, North America was 27% of our business compared to 28% last quarter. Europe and Japan each remained at 19% and 15%, respectively. Asia Pacific increased from 38% of sales to 39%. 
Turning to the rest of the income statement, gross margin was up from 75.1% to 75.7%. This is a relatively large increase on a modest sales increase. And it is unusual that cost of sales is actually less in dollars than the September quarter on higher sales volume. This results from several factors. Firstly, and obviously, the higher sales base allows us to spread factory overhead over more units sold. Secondly, gross margin in the prior quarter fell an entire point after the sharp downturn in revenue and our manufacturing plants were relatively inefficient from the quick and sudden drop in production. This turned around to some extent during the current quarter as production stabilized. Also, despite a 1 week closure during the holiday week, we have 4 more production days on average, netting the shutdown days we had in each quarter. We also had an improvement in our average selling price of $0.04 to $1.92. Finally, we had some improvement due to foreign exchange, particularly, the Malaysian ringgit, lowering the cost of our foreign plants. Overall, that nets us to a very nice gross margin under the circumstances, which is more than expected from the modest increase in sales. I do not expect a similar improvement in gross margin next quarter as we will lose some of those manufacturing efficiencies with our back end plants in Penang in Singapore closing for Chinese New Year, so I don't expect a decline either. 
R&D increased $3.3 million sequentially to $69.9 million, primarily due to higher labor cost and stock compensation from the 1 extra week in the quarter. In addition, legal costs were up slightly as were other costs such as supplies, small equipment, travel and entertainment. 
SG&A increased $3.2 million sequentially to $43.4 million, also due to the higher labor cost and stock compensation from 1 extra week in the quarter. In addition, other costs increased primarily for advertising and travel. Due to the extra week in the quarter and the holiday period that included shutdown days for all Linear employees, this was an unusual quarter for operating expenses. So our operating expense ratio at 32.2% is unusually high. Just like revenue, it is difficult to say for sure what the extra week was worth, net of the impact of the days that we shut down. And I believe you are more concerned about what the expenses will be going forward, I expect that our operating expenses with modest improvement in sales to be more in line with our first quarter in the 31% range, if not better. One thing to remember, this non-cash stock compensation is rising faster than our cash expenses as older, lower price grants best and are replaced by new higher priced grants. Recently though, it appears that the stock market is trying to take care of that difference. 
Operating income declined slightly by $0.5 million to $149.5 million, representing 43.1% of sales, again, impacted by the extra week in the quarter. Interest and another income increased $500,000 to $1.5 million. Interest income was up about $300,000 due to a slightly higher investment yield. Other income included a $200,000 foreign exchange gain on certain foreign currencies held. 
Our quarterly effective income tax rate was significantly lower this quarter at 19.5% versus 25.75% last quarter entirely due to the reinstatement of the R&D tax credit. Next quarter, absent discrete tax items, if any, we expect our annual effective tax rate to be in the 24% to 24.5% range. Net income for the period was $121.5 million, up $9.5 million, and with 35% of sales up from 32.8%. 
The average shares outstanding used in the calculation of earnings per share increased by 272,000 shares. The weighted average of stock repurchases, both this period and last period, more than offset increases from stock option exercises and vesting of employee restricted stock awards. GAAP earnings per share was $0.50, up from $0.46 in the prior quarter. Without the impact of stock-based compensation of $20.3 million, which includes an extra week of stock-based compensation expense, diluted EPS would have been $0.56 per share. 
Given the late hour here, I'm going to skip the balance sheet commentary. I'm sure there are many of you who are not disappointed by that. 
Looking forward, using the data points we have at this time, from our customers and sales force, and relying somewhat on history that suggest the weak industrial market will continue to rebound from the seasonally lower December quarter, we are guiding revenue to be up 2% to 5% sequentially in our third quarter. In the early part of this quarter, we are seeing recovery from certain geographies and certain customers. Also, the oversupply condition that occurred from the drop in demand 2 to 3 quarters ago has been mostly corrected. We believe, in general, oversupply is no longer a key issue for our OEM customers or in the distribution channel. We are seeing signs of life, but the macroeconomic climate is still fragile, so we're not calling to down cycle that began a few quarters ago over just yet. 
I would now like to open up the conference call to questions to be addressed by Bob, Lothar or me.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pretty solid execution given the macro environment out there. My first question is on the guide. Is that -- is the right way to think about it is you had -- you were shipping below demand in the quarter before December. So in December you sort of caught u
componenttext: Pretty solid execution given the macro environment out there. My first question is on the guide. Is that -- is the right way to think about it is you had -- you were shipping below demand in the quarter before December. So in December you sort of caught up to that, and now you're guiding for a quarter which seems to be more in line with seasonality. Is that the right way to think that now you are shipping mostly in sync with the demand? And then I had a quick follow-up.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's correct.
componenttext: Yes, I think that's correct.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then my follow-up is on the geographical side you mentioned that China was strong in automotives. What is your read outside of the automotive market?
componenttext: Okay, and then my follow-up is on the geographical side you mentioned that China was strong in automotives. What is your read outside of the automotive market?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, China is also a good industrial market for us. And actually, the market as you know has been relatively weak. We are seeing signs of pickup. But China has been holding its own in industrial. So that's growing as well. So you're right that transporta
componenttext: Well, China is also a good industrial market for us. And actually, the market as you know has been relatively weak. We are seeing signs of pickup. But China has been holding its own in industrial. So that's growing as well. So you're right that transportation is growing stronger, but industrial market is doing just fine in China.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we will now take a question from Craig Hettenbach from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we will now take a question from Craig Hettenbach from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Guess just following up on the China commentary, certainly there's been some stimulus down the automotive side. So just wanted to get a sense from you, as you kind of went through the quarter, just your view on the sustainability of strength in China auto
componenttext: Guess just following up on the China commentary, certainly there's been some stimulus down the automotive side. So just wanted to get a sense from you, as you kind of went through the quarter, just your view on the sustainability of strength in China autos.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the strength in the China auto business is just beginning. I mean, based on what we're seeing and based on the amount of stimulus the Chinese government is putting in place, I think we're kind of on the early stages of -- it could be a pretty good
componenttext: I think the strength in the China auto business is just beginning. I mean, based on what we're seeing and based on the amount of stimulus the Chinese government is putting in place, I think we're kind of on the early stages of -- it could be a pretty good piece of business for us. We've done very well in the BMS portion of the Chinese automotive market. And as I should say, the transportation, because it's not just cars, it's buses and taxis and vehicles as well. But -- and it's not just BMS. And if you win the BMS business in a car, you're likely to win the other sockets as well. So I think we're kind of just in the early stages of this opportunity here in transportation in China.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And just as a follow-up, just staying with automotives, China kind of stands out, but there is your concerns around North American market. Anything else more broadly on a global basis that you're seeing in automotive?
componenttext: Got it. And just as a follow-up, just staying with automotives, China kind of stands out, but there is your concerns around North American market. Anything else more broadly on a global basis that you're seeing in automotive?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's just the amount of electronics that's going into cars. So there may be some either regional or global softness in vehicle sales, but I don't think that's going to really deter the amount of electronics that goes in the cars. We spend a lot of time ta
componenttext: It's just the amount of electronics that's going into cars. So there may be some either regional or global softness in vehicle sales, but I don't think that's going to really deter the amount of electronics that goes in the cars. We spend a lot of time talking about BMS, but we've got opportunities in many other applications in the cars. There's this always ADAS stuff that people are talking about. That's just beginning. And from our perspective, we see virtually every car manufacturer having some program that deals with this ADAS. And I'm not going to say that cars are going to be driving themselves here in the next year or 2 completely by themselves. There's just a lot of stepping stones to get to that point, and we are seeing those stepping stones happening right now.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Tore Svanberg from Stifel.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Tore Svanberg from Stifel.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question, the Japan business was weak and it looks like bookings remained weak. Is there anything structural going on there, or is this just simply perhaps due to their strong currency?
componenttext: First question, the Japan business was weak and it looks like bookings remained weak. Is there anything structural going on there, or is this just simply perhaps due to their strong currency?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's an interesting question because we notice that as well that Japan is actually a little weaker than maybe some of the other regions right now. And I think there's some economic -- internal economic reasons of Japan. But I think they're being
componenttext: I think that's an interesting question because we notice that as well that Japan is actually a little weaker than maybe some of the other regions right now. And I think there's some economic -- internal economic reasons of Japan. But I think they're being affected by more than some other regions by what's going on in China. I think the imports into China are probably slowing and their consumption is more domestic, and I think Japan is feeling that. On the bookings side, we are -- the bookings going into the March quarter, March is the fiscal year end for most Japanese companies, so you get the typical sort of pushouts for shipments as they want to dress up their balance sheet a little bit. That's sort of normal seasonality. But it's more than that for sure. We think that China has something to do with it.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just as my follow-up, I know you didn't want to discuss balance sheet items, but could you just update us on the CapEx number that we should use for the fiscal year, please?
componenttext: And just as my follow-up, I know you didn't want to discuss balance sheet items, but could you just update us on the CapEx number that we should use for the fiscal year, please?

componenttext: Sure, capital expenses was about $11 million.

componenttextpreview: Okay, and what are you expecting for the year?
componenttext: Okay, and what are you expecting for the year?

componenttextpreview: Pretty similar each quarter, nothing major.
componenttext: Pretty similar each quarter, nothing major.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take a question from John Pitzer from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And we'll take a question from John Pitzer from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Don, in your prepared comments you talked about sort of daily booking trends being better thus far through January than they were in December and that when the year ending in the December quarter improved. I'm kind of curious, is that typical? And can you
componenttext: Don, in your prepared comments you talked about sort of daily booking trends being better thus far through January than they were in December and that when the year ending in the December quarter improved. I'm kind of curious, is that typical? And can you help me understand sort of normal linearity in the March quarter, especially given Chinese new year is in February this year?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chinese New Year, every year would have counted, it's not always the same week. So to be honest, it's the same -- we don't get the same pattern every year. Sometimes you get some strength going into Chinese New Year, and then maybe a little bit weakness a
componenttext: Chinese New Year, every year would have counted, it's not always the same week. So to be honest, it's the same -- we don't get the same pattern every year. Sometimes you get some strength going into Chinese New Year, and then maybe a little bit weakness afterwards. Sometimes you get a little bit of weakness before and strength afterwards. So it's not always the same pattern, but as you know, the March quarter overall is a stronger industrial quarter for us. So I think just on average, taken out sort of the macroeconomics if at all, you would generally see bookings sort of accelerate somewhat through the quarter. But again, these are not normal times.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then either for Don or for Lothar, industrial is such a large sort of umbrella bucket for all of the analog companies, yourself included. And I guess, one of the questions I'm getting is given that you are guiding to normal seasonal, r
componenttext: That's helpful. And then either for Don or for Lothar, industrial is such a large sort of umbrella bucket for all of the analog companies, yourself included. And I guess, one of the questions I'm getting is given that you are guiding to normal seasonal, roughly for the March quarter but still have kind of a cautious view on the macro, what are kind of some of the sub buckets within industrial that you guys worry about as being sort of the most macro-sensitive in an area where you could be caught by surprise if the macro remains weaker or gets weaker?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The industrial business for us is thousands of customers. So it's spread across a lot of markets. Obviously, medical is a portion of it that is doing okay. If you ask me areas where I probably and from industrial standpoint, worry about a little bit is th
componenttext: The industrial business for us is thousands of customers. So it's spread across a lot of markets. Obviously, medical is a portion of it that is doing okay. If you ask me areas where I probably and from industrial standpoint, worry about a little bit is that, we know that with the relatively low price of petroleum right now that it's affecting some of our industrial customers who have business into the exploration market. So I think we're going to see a little bit of softness on those. But I think overall, because the mix of customers and where the industrial products gets sold into, I think there's other factors that will probably balance that out. I mean, this last quarter the industrial business grew actually pretty good even in the face of those headwinds.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll now take a question from David Wong from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And we'll now take a question from David Wong from Wells Fargo.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you give us some idea, roughly how much are automotive revenues rising year-over-year for you? And what do you expect for automotive growth in 2016 or transportation?
componenttext: Could you give us some idea, roughly how much are automotive revenues rising year-over-year for you? And what do you expect for automotive growth in 2016 or transportation?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we don't -- David, I think you know by now that we don't break out the dollars or the growth rates for each of our markets. And it would be a guess anyway. But I think what we have said is you've seen a steady rise in our business of automotive from
componenttext: Well, we don't -- David, I think you know by now that we don't break out the dollars or the growth rates for each of our markets. And it would be a guess anyway. But I think what we have said is you've seen a steady rise in our business of automotive from the teens, the 20%, the 21%, it's pretty much going up almost a point quarter-to-quarter. So we sort of see that continuing, that automotive beginning to be more and more of our business. I mean, obviously, 25% is clearly within reach, and we wouldn't be surprised to see it go north from there.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016

componenttext: Yes, it increased $0.04 from $1.88 to $1.92.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
