componenttext: And we'll now take a question from William Stein from SunTrust.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm trying to reconcile your comments about the weak macro environment on the one hand with 2 other things. First, your comments about improving bookings trends and second, your 1 quarter out guidance that while in line with normal seasonality, you're com
componenttext: I'm trying to reconcile your comments about the weak macro environment on the one hand with 2 other things. First, your comments about improving bookings trends and second, your 1 quarter out guidance that while in line with normal seasonality, you're coming off of a 14-week quarter, so it would appear to be even better than what I would have expected on a seasonal basis. So can you help me sort of put those 2 together?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's a pretty good call, actually. I think you're right. I mean, we were able to still grow in a weak December quarter, but remember we came off a pretty weak quarter before that. So bookings, I would have to say, increased better than we expect
componenttext: I think that's a pretty good call, actually. I think you're right. I mean, we were able to still grow in a weak December quarter, but remember we came off a pretty weak quarter before that. So bookings, I would have to say, increased better than we expected towards the end of that December period. And now they've said, they're looking pretty good right now. Definitely a step increased over what we experienced throughout the entirety of the December quarter, but again, this is early in the quarter. There's no question, it's still weak out there. It's too early to say if the bookings will stay at that rate or even accelerate. Like John Pitzer asked before that based on history, we would expect that. But it's just too early to say. But the optimism that we have is based on what you just said. It looked pretty good towards the end of the quarter and the beginning part of this quarter.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a follow-up if I can would be whether -- maybe it's this, would you be concerned that the better bookings rate you're seeing now that's leading to the what are in a sense better than seasonal guidance could be a head fake if oil stays at the low $30 a
componenttext: So a follow-up if I can would be whether -- maybe it's this, would you be concerned that the better bookings rate you're seeing now that's leading to the what are in a sense better than seasonal guidance could be a head fake if oil stays at the low $30 a barrel that continues to pressure the whole sort of industrial complex?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a hard call to say, but if you ask me my opinion, my sense is that, that headwind we've already faced. I think it's -- we've had these relatively low prices for quite a while now, and I think most of the customers that have exposure to that market
componenttext: That's a hard call to say, but if you ask me my opinion, my sense is that, that headwind we've already faced. I think it's -- we've had these relatively low prices for quite a while now, and I think most of the customers that have exposure to that market have probably reacted already.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess so. All I wanted to add was that although we're seeing strong bookings at the beginning of this year, at the beginning of this quarter. I mean, we are still bothered by the lack of any real good macroeconomic news. And so I don't know if it's
componenttext: Yes, I guess so. All I wanted to add was that although we're seeing strong bookings at the beginning of this year, at the beginning of this quarter. I mean, we are still bothered by the lack of any real good macroeconomic news. And so I don't know if it's a head fake but we have to be mindful of that.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And, if you kind of take a longer view, well priced petroleum is probably in the long term, pretty good thing. So even there might be some near-term pain, I think long-term, this is going to be a positive.
componenttext: And, if you kind of take a longer view, well priced petroleum is probably in the long term, pretty good thing. So even there might be some near-term pain, I think long-term, this is going to be a positive.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll now take a question from Chris Caso from Susquehanna Financial Group.
componenttext: And we'll now take a question from Chris Caso from Susquehanna Financial Group.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm just wondering if you could provide just some commentary. I understand what you're seeing with the bookings itself. Maybe if you have some color about the customers themselves, what they're telling you, and you guys are in Hong Kong right now. I'm sur
componenttext: I'm just wondering if you could provide just some commentary. I understand what you're seeing with the bookings itself. Maybe if you have some color about the customers themselves, what they're telling you, and you guys are in Hong Kong right now. I'm sure you're doing some customer meetings right now. Are you getting that feeling from the customers that perhaps they're feeling a little bit better about things now, and perhaps better than what the stock market seems to be suggesting?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there's probably a different approach to the growth that we're seeing. I think if you look at all of our markets, there's 3 of them that the company has focused on for a while, the automotive, the industrial and the communications market. And the
componenttext: I think there's probably a different approach to the growth that we're seeing. I think if you look at all of our markets, there's 3 of them that the company has focused on for a while, the automotive, the industrial and the communications market. And the bookings in those -- all 3 of those markets have picked up and there wasn't really the markets that are driving our growth. And I think what we're seeing is the fact that we've concentrated our sales efforts, our product design efforts and really the markets, the analog markets that are growing. And I think that's what's helping us. I think it's less of some customers doing a great job or some market is doing well, I think we've picked the right markets and we've been at it now for quite a while. And we're seeing the benefits of it.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and as a follow on, if you could talk a bit about a little more color on what you were talking about with respect to inventory levels. I mean, it sounds like your customers were burning through inventory toward the end of last year, and perhaps some
componenttext: Okay, and as a follow on, if you could talk a bit about a little more color on what you were talking about with respect to inventory levels. I mean, it sounds like your customers were burning through inventory toward the end of last year, and perhaps some of the improvement you're seeing now is, I guess, the resumption of orders from some customers who were burning through inventory?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that we are closer. And I think this question was asked in a similarly way before. I think we're -- we feel like we're shipping to demand right now that we burned off the inventory layer that rose once the end customer demand declined. And so
componenttext: Yes, I think that we are closer. And I think this question was asked in a similarly way before. I think we're -- we feel like we're shipping to demand right now that we burned off the inventory layer that rose once the end customer demand declined. And so customers sort of took the layer down their safety stock that was -- they're expecting higher run rate so I think we burned through that and we are shipping through to actual end customer demand more or less. We think any type of major inventory correction is behind us.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: But the customers' targets for inventory haven't changed. At this point they're getting back to normal inventory levels, not raising those targets at this point?
componenttext: But the customers' targets for inventory haven't changed. At this point they're getting back to normal inventory levels, not raising those targets at this point?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I don't think what we're seeing now is they've taken inventory down and now they're adding it back. I mean, they've taken it down and now they are ordering to meet the actual demand. And so I would expect, if demand picks up as we see from beginni
componenttext: I mean, I don't think what we're seeing now is they've taken inventory down and now they're adding it back. I mean, they've taken it down and now they are ordering to meet the actual demand. And so I would expect, if demand picks up as we see from beginning part of the quarter if that was to continue, eventually some of that inventory have to be built back up. I don't think that's going on right now.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the inventory situation at the customers are still pretty lean. And we kind of normally think of the December month as being a pretty quiet month. And we actually saw some significant expedite activities from our customers where they don't ex
componenttext: Yes, I think the inventory situation at the customers are still pretty lean. And we kind of normally think of the December month as being a pretty quiet month. And we actually saw some significant expedite activities from our customers where they don't expedite us, either 1, they get surprised with an order, or 2, that they run their inventory so low that they need some extra help from us. So that was kind of a positive feel is that customers are having to expedite us for product.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think in general, our customers are confused as a lot of suppliers. They're trying to figure out which way business is moving.
componenttext: I think in general, our customers are confused as a lot of suppliers. They're trying to figure out which way business is moving.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll now take a question from Ross Seymore from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And we'll now take a question from Ross Seymore from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, one area that haven't been asked about thus far is the communication infrastructure side. You just mentioned, it's one of you 3 focus areas, I realize it stayed unchanged as a percentage of bookings. But can you talk a little bit about what you'r
componenttext: I guess, one area that haven't been asked about thus far is the communication infrastructure side. You just mentioned, it's one of you 3 focus areas, I realize it stayed unchanged as a percentage of bookings. But can you talk a little bit about what you're seeing there from the wire-line versus wireless side and maybe any geographic color as well?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's -- this market is kind of fits and starts, it stays the same as the percentage but it did obviously, grow in absolute dollars. And for us, the part of the communications market, particularly when you look towards the wireless portion, isn't in t
componenttext: Yes, it's -- this market is kind of fits and starts, it stays the same as the percentage but it did obviously, grow in absolute dollars. And for us, the part of the communications market, particularly when you look towards the wireless portion, isn't in the base station type of area. Really, the sort of non-wired or non-wireless portion is really where the growth that we are seeing. Sort of the networking -- optical is coming back to life. We were seeing as these optical applications go from 40G to 100G, to 200G to 400G. There is some really tough problems that our customers need to solve. And that particular part of market looks pretty good. There some performance issues, there's some very tight space constraints that they have to deal with. And so the sort of optical part of the business looks pretty descent.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, as my follow-up, just getting to the near-term in the March quarter, can you give us a rough idea, the turns assumption that you guys have for the March quarter this year and how that compares to maybe the December quarter and if it's a more mean
componenttext: I guess, as my follow-up, just getting to the near-term in the March quarter, can you give us a rough idea, the turns assumption that you guys have for the March quarter this year and how that compares to maybe the December quarter and if it's a more meaningful comparison to the March quarter of last year and what the actual turns were?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] I don't remember what the turns was last year, but I know that the turns that we expect this quarter probably in the 60% range, which is sort of normal. We shouldn't really -- with the kind of bookings that we expect on this kind of streng
componenttext: [indiscernible] I don't remember what the turns was last year, but I know that the turns that we expect this quarter probably in the 60% range, which is sort of normal. We shouldn't really -- with the kind of bookings that we expect on this kind of strength which we're counting on, it shouldn't be a problem, but again, we'll have to see what happens with bookings, ultimately.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from C.J. Muse from ISI Group.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from C.J. Muse from ISI Group.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, getting back to the seasonal guide in this macro uncertainty, just curious if you can talk a little bit about whether you think this is -- leverage the right sub segments in terms of end markets whether rising content and/or a la higher ASPs as y
componenttext: I guess, getting back to the seasonal guide in this macro uncertainty, just curious if you can talk a little bit about whether you think this is -- leverage the right sub segments in terms of end markets whether rising content and/or a la higher ASPs as you alluded to, would love to hear just color on that front.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Honestly, I don't understand what you're asking for. I mean, [indiscernible] would be that, so I would maybe get another.
componenttext: Honestly, I don't understand what you're asking for. I mean, [indiscernible] would be that, so I would maybe get another.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. Trying to balance seasonal guide with macro uncertainty and there, just wondering, are you just leverage simply to the rights of end-markets that you've been attacking over the last couple of years? Is it a rise in content story for you? Is it
componenttext: Yes, sure. Trying to balance seasonal guide with macro uncertainty and there, just wondering, are you just leverage simply to the rights of end-markets that you've been attacking over the last couple of years? Is it a rise in content story for you? Is it a rising ASP? Really trying to better understand the drivers there.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think you hit it on the head, is that, it's -- there are headwinds, obviously, that are out there, but I think we've, either through good fortune, luck, or brilliance had picked the right markets to go after. And even though there are some economic
componenttext: Yes, I think you hit it on the head, is that, it's -- there are headwinds, obviously, that are out there, but I think we've, either through good fortune, luck, or brilliance had picked the right markets to go after. And even though there are some economic headwinds, the content in the automotive market, which has been our fastest growing end market, just has accelerated and will probably continue to accelerate for quite a while. So I think we're seeing some growth here, partially because of seasonality. But I think, at least this is important is the fact that our products and our sales efforts and our design efforts are in the markets that seem to be doing relatively well. I say this all the time and it surprises people is the -- if you look at the total analog market, the industrial and the automotives make up 50% of the total analog market. Not us, but the total analog market. And we -- that's where the majority of our business is directed towards. So we're kind of focused really in the growth areas of the analog market and we seem to be doing pretty well right now.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And I guess, as a quick follow-up, can you walk through the moving parts again in terms of what we should be expecting for gross margin in terms of mixed ASP FX?
componenttext: That's helpful. And I guess, as a quick follow-up, can you walk through the moving parts again in terms of what we should be expecting for gross margin in terms of mixed ASP FX?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: As I stated in the opening commentary, quite honestly, that to get a 60 base improvement on a little over $5 million increase in sales is unusual. So there is a lot of moving parts in there. So it's difficult to say going forward, which of those parts wil
componenttext: As I stated in the opening commentary, quite honestly, that to get a 60 base improvement on a little over $5 million increase in sales is unusual. So there is a lot of moving parts in there. So it's difficult to say going forward, which of those parts will continue. I do know for sure that there is a slight headwind if you call it that, just that we know we are closing down our back-end factory and so less production days means some inefficiencies, less absorption. So that affects us.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] effects of Chinese new year.
componenttext: [indiscernible] effects of Chinese new year.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the Chinese new year on Singapore and in Malaysia. But the ASP, certainly helps and that's mixed. But I can't say what just yet what mix is going to be in the current quarter. I will say that in fairness to our factories, it wasn't just number of pro
componenttext: Yes, the Chinese new year on Singapore and in Malaysia. But the ASP, certainly helps and that's mixed. But I can't say what just yet what mix is going to be in the current quarter. I will say that in fairness to our factories, it wasn't just number of production days, I mean, there's some real P&L improvement and some cost-saving efforts that they've achieved. But in terms of color going forward, I do expect -- I don't expect another 60 base improvement in gross margin on a higher sales growth if we actually hit our target. So I'm a little cautious about saying that. I wouldn't expect even with the shutdown of our back-end factories for Chinese new year so I wouldn't expect it to decline. Hopefully, we'll get some improvement but it's too early to know. Just like you said, there's just a lot of moving pieces.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we will now take our next question from Craig Ellis from B. Riley.
componenttext: And we will now take our next question from Craig Ellis from B. Riley.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first is just a follow-up on your comments, Lothar, around the automotive business. I just want to ensure I'm understanding how your business is evolving. Are you saying that content growth is accelerating because we're starting to see some of the mor
componenttext: The first is just a follow-up on your comments, Lothar, around the automotive business. I just want to ensure I'm understanding how your business is evolving. Are you saying that content growth is accelerating because we're starting to see some of the more advanced systems in traditional automobiles. Or content growth accelerating for Linear Tech because as the TAM expands to include things like buses and other mass transit type systems, you've just got a blended content growth rate that's better than when it's been recently?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it is a little bit of both. And clearly, you spend that time 10 years ago, there wasn't a lot of electronics. There is the NAV and the entertainment systems and that's where really most of the electronics was concentrated in a car. Now you've got
componenttext: I think it is a little bit of both. And clearly, you spend that time 10 years ago, there wasn't a lot of electronics. There is the NAV and the entertainment systems and that's where really most of the electronics was concentrated in a car. Now you've got all sorts of drive-by wires, you got LED lighting, you've got VMS, you got hybrid and electric cars and that's because we work with the car companies and we already know model year of '17, '18, '19 what sort of electronic content they're going to have. And there's just a tremendous amount of new opportunities. Things like 48-volt battery systems, they're coming. They're -- I think there's already model year '16, '17, there's a couple of car companies that will have 48-volt battery systems. And then that just opens up a whole new area. And I think it will probably helps us a lot as well as the fact that there's been some geographies particularly, China that's pushing very hard on alternatively fueled vehicles, and so it's just -- and we talked about this ADAS stuff that's coming. And so it's really just a lot of new opportunities for electronics that's really helping us in the automotive market. And you asked me if it's exhilarating. I think to some extent, probably yes. I mean, we could see opportunity upon opportunity in that market.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The follow-up, Don, nice $0.02 dividend increase for the second consecutive multi-penny increase for the company. Where are we with respect to an optimal level as a percent of free cash flow for your dividend payment now?
componenttext: The follow-up, Don, nice $0.02 dividend increase for the second consecutive multi-penny increase for the company. Where are we with respect to an optimal level as a percent of free cash flow for your dividend payment now?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: An optimal number for our cash flow? Well, I think what we've said is, to be honest, it's we don't have an optimal level of cash flow. I mean, we think that the increase in the dividend year in and year out is sort of our first commitment to our sharehold
componenttext: An optimal number for our cash flow? Well, I think what we've said is, to be honest, it's we don't have an optimal level of cash flow. I mean, we think that the increase in the dividend year in and year out is sort of our first commitment to our shareholders in the return of that capital. We've done that every year since we've commenced it. And then secondarily, at a minimum, we try to retire the shares that are issued to employees. But first and foremost is the dividend, and absent something unforeseen, we expect to increase that every year as long as we can. It's not based upon some optimal level of cash flow.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll now go to Harlan Sur from JPMorgan.
componenttext: And we'll now go to Harlan Sur from JPMorgan.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: In your prepared remarks, you mentioned you're seeing positive demand signs in certain geo's and end markets this quarter. I know it's early days for the team but can you just give us a bit more color on what areas and geo's you have seen the positive dem
componenttext: In your prepared remarks, you mentioned you're seeing positive demand signs in certain geo's and end markets this quarter. I know it's early days for the team but can you just give us a bit more color on what areas and geo's you have seen the positive demand pull this quarter? I know industrial and auto are typically stronger but any color would be great.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, I think, certainly, Asia Pacific is showing strength. We talked about China, but Korea is doing pretty well. Europe is a little weak but we see some signs there. Japan, we already talked about is it's somewhat weak and being affected by Chin
componenttext: Well, I mean, I think, certainly, Asia Pacific is showing strength. We talked about China, but Korea is doing pretty well. Europe is a little weak but we see some signs there. Japan, we already talked about is it's somewhat weak and being affected by China. Then within Europe, I said Europe is sort of holding its own, it's not strong but it's not really weak either, but within Europe, there's different countries that are affected. I think Germany is being affected a little bit by China as well, so Germany, obviously, a big piece of Europe, but I think they are a little weak right now but I wouldn't say very weak. So it's -- we're still broad based so it's difficult to say which country, but I -- it looks like we're showing a little bit of strength in general, we'll just have to see if that continues.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then were there any differences in bookings momentum between disti and OEM customers in December? And what are the trends that you're seeing OEM versus disti this quarter?
componenttext: Great. And then were there any differences in bookings momentum between disti and OEM customers in December? And what are the trends that you're seeing OEM versus disti this quarter?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually I think between OEM and disti, OEM actually bounced back a little better than distribution. Distribution was somewhat flattish to maybe down a little bit. But nothing inordinate. We would hope that just like the rest of our internal business, our
componenttext: Actually I think between OEM and disti, OEM actually bounced back a little better than distribution. Distribution was somewhat flattish to maybe down a little bit. But nothing inordinate. We would hope that just like the rest of our internal business, our directive is that, that distribution will grow along with us.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I will now take a question from Steve Smigie from Raymond James.
componenttext: I will now take a question from Steve Smigie from Raymond James.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to touch a little bit more on China industrial. You mentioned some strength there. Obviously, it's broad based. Are there a couple of markets of strength there that's doing a little bit better? Factory automation, for example, and is that st
componenttext: I just wanted to touch a little bit more on China industrial. You mentioned some strength there. Obviously, it's broad based. Are there a couple of markets of strength there that's doing a little bit better? Factory automation, for example, and is that strength more around their units are starting to do a bit better again, or is it you guys are just again gaining a lot of dollar content on the boxes?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, that's an area that is pretty hard to pin down because it is so broad, there are so many different customers, they buy such a diverse build materials. But from reviewing Asia right now, and with discussions with the sales team, you kind of hit it o
componenttext: Again, that's an area that is pretty hard to pin down because it is so broad, there are so many different customers, they buy such a diverse build materials. But from reviewing Asia right now, and with discussions with the sales team, you kind of hit it on the head, some of the interesting areas in industrial, which maybe isn't helping exactly right now, but may in the near future is sort of automation area. There's a lot of talk about it here. We see customer interest in that area. And so that may be something that's interesting going forward, for LTC.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And just my follow-up question was around inventory, you talked about that getting cleaned up. Can you help us understand a little bit in terms of that cleanup, is it more cleanup on the channel side, the distributors or is it OEM? And on the
componenttext: Okay, great. And just my follow-up question was around inventory, you talked about that getting cleaned up. Can you help us understand a little bit in terms of that cleanup, is it more cleanup on the channel side, the distributors or is it OEM? And on the channel side, where did you see the biggest change? Is it the big [indiscernible] out there? Or is it local Chinese guys where you've seen the change?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, to be honest, I don't think I have that information nor I recall the distribution inventory by region. But in terms of when the inventory had to come down because demand itself, I think there was inventory correction that affected OEM and distribution
componenttext: No, to be honest, I don't think I have that information nor I recall the distribution inventory by region. But in terms of when the inventory had to come down because demand itself, I think there was inventory correction that affected OEM and distribution equally. It had to be done on both channels. But in terms of what part of the channel, where it was greater and now it's bounced back, I honestly don't know. I don't have the information broken down like that.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We will now take a question from Vivek Arya from Bank of America.
componenttext: We will now take a question from Vivek Arya from Bank of America.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's a lot of concern about just currency devaluation in China, and just FX fluctuations, I'd realize the semiconductor companies usually price in dollars. But I'm wondering if it's having any direct or indirect impact on your business? And does it eve
componenttext: There's a lot of concern about just currency devaluation in China, and just FX fluctuations, I'd realize the semiconductor companies usually price in dollars. But I'm wondering if it's having any direct or indirect impact on your business? And does it even come up in discussions with your OEM or distributor customers?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think I've answered this question before in the past. We're not going to say it has no effect. Like you said, we're a U.S. dollar company, our competitors also price in US dollars. It certainly has some effect. You mentioned specifically China, and I do
componenttext: I think I've answered this question before in the past. We're not going to say it has no effect. Like you said, we're a U.S. dollar company, our competitors also price in US dollars. It certainly has some effect. You mentioned specifically China, and I don't ever remember coming up in an internal conversation about price foreign currency issues we got within China, that's for sure. But just in general, there's the movement of foreign currency to have some pick -- some effects on our revenues, I'm sure the answer to that is yes, but it's never been great, whether the dollar is strong or whether the dollar is weak. It's probably little, but I wouldn't say it's significant in either direction.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as a quick follow-up, you have a very strong balance sheet, over $1.3 billion in cash. Does this current environment make you think more about either doing more buybacks or thinking about any other M&A in the industry? Or do you think just caution in
componenttext: And as a quick follow-up, you have a very strong balance sheet, over $1.3 billion in cash. Does this current environment make you think more about either doing more buybacks or thinking about any other M&A in the industry? Or do you think just caution in the environment makes you not think about those things more actively?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mentioned M&A. We're not a big player in that field. And so when we -- in the past, we did a large transaction in 2007. When we felt our strategy was not well understood and that's when we're focusing more on automotive and industrial. We retired that
componenttext: You mentioned M&A. We're not a big player in that field. And so when we -- in the past, we did a large transaction in 2007. When we felt our strategy was not well understood and that's when we're focusing more on automotive and industrial. We retired that debt a little over a year ago. We've been using our existing cash to retire shares, and we've done that, we bought back at least those that we've issued. That's sort of our secondary cause, if you will, behind this dividend. But it's -- in terms of something going forward, we'll have to just wait and see.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll now take a question from Stephen Chin from UBS.
componenttext: And we'll now take a question from Stephen Chin from UBS.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: First one is on your automotive business. I just wanted to see if you can help parse out a little bit more of some of the exposures in that business? When you look across the whole product line, can you break out the growth of exposure between gasoline ca
componenttext: First one is on your automotive business. I just wanted to see if you can help parse out a little bit more of some of the exposures in that business? When you look across the whole product line, can you break out the growth of exposure between gasoline cars versus also major cars like hybrids and electrics, if that's possible? And also just with the long sort of design wins, because it's all you have and where your approximately going to? Any sense for whether your [indiscernible] maybe concentrated in sort of high to mid end vehicles or are you seeing approximately down towards mid and then -- and also mass market vehicles as well.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Initially, when we started to see a pickup in the automotive business, it was really dominated by conventional gasoline powered cars. That is starting to evolve and it's -- as more car OEMs field electric and hybrid and plug-in hybrid cars, even those tod
componenttext: Initially, when we started to see a pickup in the automotive business, it was really dominated by conventional gasoline powered cars. That is starting to evolve and it's -- as more car OEMs field electric and hybrid and plug-in hybrid cars, even those today, the quantity of those cars are still relatively small, the content of opportunities for Linear are significantly higher, multiple tire in those types of cars. So the hybrid and electric vehicle market is a very interesting market for us because it has a much, much higher electronic content for us. So that's where we're seeing some pretty significant opportunities. But there's the sort of waves of new areas for electronics that are coming in the cars. I mentioned earlier, the 48-volt battery system, that's going to have a wave of opportunities. ADAS systems is going to have a wave of opportunities. And we're just seeing these waves of opportunities coming in, and I think there's just a lot of good opportunities for vehicles right now and we've seen the benefit of it in the last several years where we've seen pretty steady growth in our automotive sales and also in the percentage of our sales going into the automotive market. So I hope that answered part of your question.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's helpful. And just as a quick follow-up, I'm not sure if I missed this -- of a comment earlier, but for your front end fab utilization rates for the March quarter, is that going to be down or flat for the quarter?
componenttext: Yes, that's helpful. And just as a quick follow-up, I'm not sure if I missed this -- of a comment earlier, but for your front end fab utilization rates for the March quarter, is that going to be down or flat for the quarter?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the March quarter, it should be, I think in terms of the number of production days, it's probably going to be about flat. I mentioned it's the back-end to our assembly and test operation overseas that is going to celebrate Chinese New Year. So they'll
componenttext: In the March quarter, it should be, I think in terms of the number of production days, it's probably going to be about flat. I mentioned it's the back-end to our assembly and test operation overseas that is going to celebrate Chinese New Year. So they'll have less production days. The fab will be about the same.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And gentlemen, it appears we have no more telephone questions at this time.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Linear Technology Corporation Fiscal 2016 Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Don Zerio, Vice President of Finance and Chief
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Linear Technology Corporation Fiscal 2016 Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Don Zerio, Vice President of Finance and Chief Financial Officer. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Welcome to the Linear Technology conference call. I am joined today by Bob Swanson, our Executive Chairman; and Lothar Maier, our CEO. Firstly, I would like to mention that we are hosting this call from Hong Kong, where it is 12:30 A.M. So I
componenttext:
Good morning. Welcome to the Linear Technology conference call. I am joined today by Bob Swanson, our Executive Chairman; and Lothar Maier, our CEO. Firstly, I would like to mention that we are hosting this call from Hong Kong, where it is 12:30 A.M. So I intend to keep my opening comments brief, and hopefully, you will cut us some slack during the Q&A given the late hour. Secondly, I would like to remind you that in our presentation today and our answers to certain questions that may follow, we may make forward-looking statements that are dependent on certain risk and uncertainties, including, but not limited to, our financial results for future periods; our ability to produce and sell existing products; the timely introduction of new products and processes; and general conditions in the world economy and financial markets. In addition to these risks, please refer to the risk factors listed in the company's annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended June 28, 2015. Also, SEC Regulation FD regarding selective disclosure influences our interaction with investors. Accordingly, this conference call will be our forum to respond to questions regarding our estimated financial performance going forward. Should you have questions regarding our estimates of sales and profits or other financial matters for the upcoming quarter, this is the time we are free to respond to your questions. 
As noted on our press release, which was released yesterday just after the market closed, revenue for the December quarter came in at the midpoint of our guidance at $347.1 million, up 1.5% from the September quarter. Due to higher sales, more production days and related manufacturing efficiencies, gross margin increased from 75.1% to 75.7%. Operating income was affected by the extra week this quarter as the extra week added higher operating expenses, primarily in labor-related costs, including stock compensations, though certain other operational cost increase as well. 
Just to clarify, fiscal 2016 is a fiscal 53-week year, and we add that week to the December quarter, making it a 14-week quarter versus the typical 13 weeks. As a result of the added expenses, operating income dropped to 43.1% of sales versus 43.8% last quarter. Net income received a benefit from a lower tax rate of 19.5% compared to 25.75% in Q1 due to the permanent reinstatement of the R&D tax credit. Net income and earnings per share were $121.5 million and $0.50, of which $0.04 was due to the lower tax rate. 
For the 24th conservative year since the company began paying a dividend, the Board of Directors has once again approved a dividend increase, raising the dividend $0.02 to $0.32 per share payable on February 24, 2016. Recent history shows that the December quarter is usually a down quarter for us, in part due to seasonality. So we are pleased that we showed some sequential growth in a difficult economic environment. Yes, we had an extra week to record revenue, but as I indicated last quarter, the calendar year-end timing of that extra week typically does not translate into much additional revenue. That, in fact, turned out to be true. 
It is difficult to say exactly what that amount was due to year-end shipment patterns and the lack of full visibility of third party POS data, but we believe it was not much at all, if any, on the direct OEM business, and it is definitely less than 2 extra days on average, I estimated it might be, from distribution. While I can't say for certain how much it was so I won't guess and I'll let you make your own estimate. 
Bookings on the other hand are easier to quantify, and they did pick up at the end of the month. Unlike sales, we did get about 3 additional days of bookings on average from the extra week, which is more than we expected for that period. In the early part of the current quarter, bookings per day have improved over the December quarter and a positive book-to-bill ratio has given us some extra backlog heading into the March quarter. That gives us reason for optimism, as the macroeconomic picture is no better than last quarter, if it is not worse, and all we have to do is read the paper and check the markets to know that. 
Naturally there's a lot of caution out there among our customers. In light of all this, we are currently projecting revenue to be up 2% to 5% in the March quarter. This forecast assumes that the current run rate for bookings does not slow considerably, and that the industrial market continues to improve from the recent low we saw in the September quarter. These are not assumptions that can be guaranteed in the current economic climate. 
Turning to bookings by region and market sector. As a reminder, we have posted bookings by market and revenue by geography for the quarter on our website at linear.com. Just click Company, Investor Relations and Supplemental Information. We post this information by the end of our business day on the day we release our results. Total bookings increased for the quarter and we had a positive book-to-bill ratio. Bookings increased in both North America and the international market. Within international, bookings were up in Europe and Asia Pacific but were down in Japan. Despite the relative turmoil in the China market, it continues to be a bright spot as bookings were up the most in that geographic region on the strength of automotive. 
With respect to bookings by market sector, our 3 biggest markets -- industrial, transportation and communications -- were all up modestly led by transportation in both dollars and as a percentage. Of our smaller markets, military, space was up following the weak September quarter, while computer and consumer were both down. The computer market, particularly PCs and notebooks, continue to be particularly weak, and we are certainly not alone in feeling that. 
Industrial continues to be our largest market at 43% of our bookings, the same as the previous quarter, but we did see some improvement in bookings as we hoped coming off a weak Q1. The increase in bookings was led by North America followed by Asia Pacific and Europe. Japan was essentially flat. We are encouraged by the increase as a whole, but we would not yet characterize it as a sign of strength as we are still a ways from the bookings level we had a year or so ago. Someone characterized it as less weak, and I think that is a good way to put it right now. 
March is historically a stronger industrial quarter, so this quarter should shed some better light. The overall increase in bookings was led by transportation, which increased to 23% of our business, up from 22%. The increase in bookings in transportation was driven primarily by Asia Pacific, and to a lesser extent, Europe, while North America was flat and Japan was down. Asia Pacific is showing continued strength from China due in large part to the success of our battery management products for hybrid and electric vehicles. China is currently offering significant incentives to both businesses and consumers to build and buy electric, and our BMS products have helped us capitalize on that. Korea is also a good transportation market for us as well in Asia Pacific. 
Bookings in the communications market increased as North America bookings bounced back a bit from a weak first quarter. Europe and Asia were up as well, but just slightly, and Japan was flat. Communications remained at 18% of our bookings for the quarter. 
The computer market was 7% of our bookings, down from 9% last quarter with the decrease primarily in North America, where the majority of this business is booked. As stated previously, this market is suffering due to weaker notebook sales, and to a lesser extent, storage devices such as solid state drives. This market may continue to atrophy a bit for us over the short term as notebook sales continue to decline as expected. Longer term, we are still very much in this market and expect growth opportunity to come to fruition as we have products that address the high end of this market. 
Bookings for military, space and harsh environment products were higher this quarter, pushing its share back to 6% of our business as has been the norm. Military bounced back from a weak first quarter, while the space business has been somewhat flat for the past year. We do expect the space business to improve as satellite launch activity picks up. This is predominantly a U.S. market, though we do book some business in Europe. 
Finally, consumer, our smallest end market and one we don't focus on, remained at 3% of our bookings though bookings were down in the quarter. With regard to where our bookings are actually created, 62% were created internationally, and 38% in North America versus 61% and 39% respectively last period. 
Moving on to sales. Sales increased by 1.5% from the prior quarter and were down 1.5% from the prior year quarter. Geographically, sales were up in both North America and rest of world, which is primarily Asia Pacific. Europe was essentially flat, while Japan was down. On a regional basis, North America was 27% of our business compared to 28% last quarter. Europe and Japan each remained at 19% and 15%, respectively. Asia Pacific increased from 38% of sales to 39%. 
Turning to the rest of the income statement, gross margin was up from 75.1% to 75.7%. This is a relatively-large increase on a modest sales increase. And it is unusual that cost of sales is actually less in dollars than the September quarter on higher sales volume. This results from several factors. Firstly, and obviously, the higher sales base allows us to spread factory overhead over more units sold. Secondly, gross margin in the prior quarter fell an entire point after the sharp downturn in revenue and our manufacturing plants were relatively inefficient from the quick and sudden drop in production. This turned around to some extent during the current quarter as production stabilized. Also, despite a 1 week closure during the holiday week, we had 4 more production days on average, netting the shutdown days we had in each quarter. We also had an improvement in our average selling price of $0.04 to $1.92. Finally, we had some improvement due to foreign exchange, particularly, the Malaysian ringgit, lowering the cost of our foreign plants. Overall, that nets off to a very nice gross margin under the circumstances, which is more than expected from the modest increase in sales. I do not expect a similar improvement in gross margin next quarter as we will lose some of those manufacturing efficiencies with our back-end plants in Penang and Singapore closing for Chinese New Year, though I don't expect a decline either. 
R&D increased $3.3 million sequentially to $69.9 million, primarily due to higher labor cost and stock compensation from the 1 extra week in the quarter. In addition, legal costs were up slightly as were other costs such as supplies, small equipment, travel and entertainment. 
SG&A increased $3.2 million sequentially to $43.4 million, also due to the higher labor cost and stock compensation from 1 extra week in the quarter. In addition, other costs increased primarily for advertising and travel. Due to the extra week in the quarter and the holiday period that included shutdown days for all Linear employees, this was an unusual quarter for operating expenses. So our operating expense ratio at 32.2% is unusually high. Just like revenue, it is difficult to say for sure what the extra week was worth, net of the impact of the days that we shut down. As I believe you are more concerned about what the expenses will be going forward, I expect that our operating expenses with modest improvement in sales to be more in line with our first quarter in the 31% range, if not better. One thing to remember, is non-cash stock compensation is rising faster than our cash expenses as older, lower priced grants best [ph] and are replaced by new higher-priced grants [ph] . Recently though, it appears that the stock market is trying to take care of that difference. 
Operating income declined slightly by $0.5 million to $149.5 million, representing 43.1% of sales, again, impacted by the extra week in the quarter. Interest and another income increased from $500k to $1.5 million. Interest income was up about $300k due to a slightly higher investment yield. Other income included a $200k foreign exchange gain on certain foreign currencies held. 
Our quarterly effective income tax rate was significantly lower this quarter at 19.5% versus 25.75% last quarter entirely due to the reinstatement of the R&D tax credit. Next quarter, absent discrete tax items, if any, we expect our annual effective tax rate to be in the 24% to 24.5% range. Net income for the period was $121.5 million, up $9.5 million, and with 35% of sales up from 32.8%. 
The average shares outstanding used in the calculation of earnings per share increased by 272,000 shares. The weighted average of stock repurchases, both this period and last period, more than offset increases from stock option exercises and vesting of employee-restricted stock awards. GAAP earnings per share was $0.50, up from $0.46 in the prior quarter. Without the impact of stock-based compensation of $20.3 million, which includes an extra week of stock-based compensation expense, diluted EPS would have been $0.56 per share. 
Given the late hour here, I'm going to skip the balance sheet commentary. I'm sure there are many of you who are not disappointed by that. 
Looking forward. Using the data points we have at this time, from our customers and sales force, and relying somewhat on history that suggests the weak industrial market will continue to rebound from the seasonally lower December quarter, we are guiding revenue to be up 2% to 5% sequentially in our third quarter. In the early part of this quarter, we are seeing recovery from certain geographies and certain customers. Also, the oversupply condition that occurred from the drop in demand 2 to 3 quarters ago has been mostly corrected. We believe, in general, oversupply is no longer a key issue for our OEM customers or in the distribution channel. We are seeing signs of life, but the macroeconomic climate is still fragile, so we're not calling the down cycle that began a few quarters ago, over just yet. 
I would now like to open up the conference call to questions to be addressed by Bob, Lothar or me.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016

componenttext: Pretty solid execution given the macro environment out there. My first question is on the guide. Is that -- is the right way to think about it is you had -- you were shipping below demand in the quarter before December. So in December you sort of caught up to that, and now you're guiding for a quarter which seems to be more in line with seasonality. Is that the right way to think that now you are shipping mostly in sync with the demand? And then I had a quick follow-up.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's correct.
componenttext: Yes, I think that's correct.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016

componenttext: Okay, and then my follow-up is on the geographical side you mentioned that China was strong in automotives. What is your read outside of the automotive market?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, China is also a good industrial market for us. And actually, the market as you know has been relatively weak. We are seeing signs of pickup. But China has been holding its own in industrial. So that's growing as well. So you're right that transporta
componenttext: Well, China is also a good industrial market for us. And actually, the market as you know has been relatively weak. We are seeing signs of pickup. But China has been holding its own in industrial. So that's growing as well. So you're right that transportation is growing stronger, but industrial market is doing just fine in China.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we will now take a question from Craig Hettenbach from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we will now take a question from Craig Hettenbach from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, just following up on the China commentary, certainly there's been some stimulus down the automotive side. So just wanted to get a sense from you, as you kind of went through the quarter, just your view on the sustainability of strength in China autos
componenttext: Yes, just following up on the China commentary, certainly there's been some stimulus down the automotive side. So just wanted to get a sense from you, as you kind of went through the quarter, just your view on the sustainability of strength in China autos.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the strength in the China auto business is just beginning. I mean, based on what we're seeing and based on the amount of stimulus the Chinese government is putting in place, I think we're kind of on the early stages of -- it could be a pretty good
componenttext: I think the strength in the China auto business is just beginning. I mean, based on what we're seeing and based on the amount of stimulus the Chinese government is putting in place, I think we're kind of on the early stages of -- it could be a pretty good piece of business for us. We've done very well in the BMS portion of the Chinese automotive market -- and actually I should say, the transportation, because it's not just cars; it's buses and taxis and vehicles as well. But -- and it's not just BMS. And if you win the BMS business in a car, you're likely to win the other sockets as well. So I think we're kind of just in the early stages of this opportunity here in transportation in China.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And just as a follow-up, just staying with automotives. China kind of stands out, but there is concerns around North American market. Anything else more broadly on a global basis that you're seeing in automotive?
componenttext: Got it. And just as a follow-up, just staying with automotives. China kind of stands out, but there is concerns around North American market. Anything else more broadly on a global basis that you're seeing in automotive?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's just the amount of electronics that's going into cars. So there may be some either regional or global softness in vehicle sales, but I don't think that's going to really deter the amount of electronics that goes into cars. We spend a lot of time talk
componenttext: It's just the amount of electronics that's going into cars. So there may be some either regional or global softness in vehicle sales, but I don't think that's going to really deter the amount of electronics that goes into cars. We spend a lot of time talking about BMS, but we've got opportunities in many other applications in the cars. There's this -- all this ADAS stuff that people are talking about. That's just beginning. And from our perspective, we see virtually every car manufacturer having some program that deals with this ADAS. And I'm not going to say that cars are going to be driving themselves here in the next year or 2 completely by themselves. There's just a lot of stepping stones to get to that point, and we are seeing those stepping stones happening right now.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Tore Svanberg from Stifel.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Tore Svanberg from Stifel.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question, the Japan business was weak and it looks like bookings remained weak. Is there anything structural going on there, or is this just simply perhaps due to their strong currency?
componenttext: First question, the Japan business was weak and it looks like bookings remained weak. Is there anything structural going on there, or is this just simply perhaps due to their strong currency?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's an interesting question because we noticed that as well that Japan is actually a little weaker than maybe some of the other regions right now. And I think there's some economic -- internal economic reasons of Japan. But I think they're bein
componenttext: I think that's an interesting question because we noticed that as well that Japan is actually a little weaker than maybe some of the other regions right now. And I think there's some economic -- internal economic reasons of Japan. But I think they're being affected by more than some other regions by what's going on in China. I think the imports into China are probably slowing and their consumption is more domestic, and I think Japan is feeling that. On the bookings side, we are -- the bookings going into the March quarter -- March is the fiscal year end for most Japanese companies, so you get the typical sort of pushouts for shipments as they want to dress up their balance sheet a little bit. And that's sort of normal seasonality. But it's more than that for sure. We think that China has something to do with it.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just as my follow-up, I know you didn't want to discuss balance sheet items, but could you just update us on the CapEx number that we should use for the fiscal year, please?
componenttext: And just as my follow-up, I know you didn't want to discuss balance sheet items, but could you just update us on the CapEx number that we should use for the fiscal year, please?

componenttext: Sure, capital expenses was about $11 million.

componenttext: Okay, and what are you expecting for the year?

componenttext: Pretty similar each quarter, nothing major.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take a question from John Pitzer from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And we'll take a question from John Pitzer from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Don, in your prepared comments you talked about sort of daily booking trends being better thus far through January than they were in December and that linearity in the December quarter improved. I'm kind of curious, is that typical? And can you help me un
componenttext: Don, in your prepared comments you talked about sort of daily booking trends being better thus far through January than they were in December and that linearity in the December quarter improved. I'm kind of curious, is that typical? And can you help me understand sort of normal linearity in the March quarter, especially given Chinese new year is in February this year?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chinese New Year, every year when it comes, it's not always the same week. So to be honest, it's the same -- we don't get the same pattern every year. Sometimes you get some strength going into Chinese New Year, and then maybe a little bit weakness afterw
componenttext: Chinese New Year, every year when it comes, it's not always the same week. So to be honest, it's the same -- we don't get the same pattern every year. Sometimes you get some strength going into Chinese New Year, and then maybe a little bit weakness afterwards. Sometimes you get a little bit of weakness before and strength afterwards. So it's not always the same pattern, but as you know, the March quarter overall is a stronger industrial quarter for us. So I think just on average, taking out sort of the macroeconomics if at all, you would generally see bookings sort of accelerate somewhat through the quarter. But again, these are not normal times.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then either for Don or for Lothar, industrial is such a large sort of umbrella bucket for all of the analog companies, yourself included. And I guess, one of the questions I'm getting is given that you are guiding to normal seasonal, r
componenttext: That's helpful. And then either for Don or for Lothar, industrial is such a large sort of umbrella bucket for all of the analog companies, yourself included. And I guess, one of the questions I'm getting is given that you are guiding to normal seasonal, roughly for the March quarter, but still have kind of a cautious view on the macro, what are kind of some of the sub-buckets within industrial that you guys worry about as being sort of the most macro-sensitive in an area where you could be caught by surprise if the macro remains weak or gets weaker?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The industrial business for us is thousands of customers. So it's spread across a lot of markets. Obviously, medical is a portion of it that is doing okay. If you ask me areas where I probably and from industrial standpoint, worry about a little bit is th
componenttext: The industrial business for us is thousands of customers. So it's spread across a lot of markets. Obviously, medical is a portion of it that is doing okay. If you ask me areas where I probably and from industrial standpoint, worry about a little bit is that, we know that with the relatively-low price of petroleum right now that it's affecting some of our industrial customers who have business into the exploration market. So I think we're going to see a little bit of softness on those. But I think overall, because of the mix of customers and where the industrial products gets sold into, I think there's other factors that will probably balance that out. I mean, this last quarter the industrial business grew actually pretty good even in the face of those headwinds.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll now take a question from David Wong from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And we'll now take a question from David Wong from Wells Fargo.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you give us some idea, roughly how much are automotive revenues rising year-over-year for you? And what do you expect for automotive growth in 2016 or transportation?
componenttext: Could you give us some idea, roughly how much are automotive revenues rising year-over-year for you? And what do you expect for automotive growth in 2016 or transportation?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we don't -- David, I think you know by now that we don't break out the dollars or the growth rates for each of our markets. And it would be a guess anyway. But I think what we have said is you've seen a steady rise in our business of automotive from
componenttext: Well, we don't -- David, I think you know by now that we don't break out the dollars or the growth rates for each of our markets. And it would be a guess anyway. But I think what we have said is you've seen a steady rise in our business of automotive from the teens, the 20%, the 21%, it's pretty much been going up almost a point quarter-to-quarter. So we sort of see that continuing, that automotive beginning to be more and more of our business. I mean, obviously, 25% is clearly within reach, and we wouldn't be surprised to see it go north of there.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, and my follow-up, Forgive me if I missed this but did you say what ASP was during the quarter?
componenttext: Great, and my follow-up, Forgive me if I missed this but did you say what ASP was during the quarter?
