headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm trying to reconcile your comments about the weak macro environment on the one hand with 2 other things. First, your comments about improving bookings trends and second, your one quarter out guidance that while in line with normal seasonality, you're c
componenttext: I'm trying to reconcile your comments about the weak macro environment on the one hand with 2 other things. First, your comments about improving bookings trends and second, your one quarter out guidance that while in line with normal seasonality, you're coming off of a 14-week quarter so it would appear to be even better than what I would have expected on a seasonal basis. So can you help me sort of put those 2 together?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's a pretty good call, actually. I think you're right. I mean, we were able to still grow in a weak December quarter, but remember we came off a pretty weak quarter before that. So bookings, I would have to say, increased better than we expect
componenttext: I think that's a pretty good call, actually. I think you're right. I mean, we were able to still grow in a weak December quarter, but remember we came off a pretty weak quarter before that. So bookings, I would have to say, increased better than we expected towards the end of that December period. And as I said, they're looking pretty good right now. There's definitely a step-increase  over what we experienced throughout the entirety of the December quarter, but again, this is early in the quarter. There's no question, it's still weak out there. It's too early to say if the bookings will stay at that rate or even accelerate. Like John Pitzer asked before, that based on history, we would expect that. But it's just too early to say. But the optimism that we have is based on what you just said. It looked pretty good towards the end of the quarter and the beginning part of this quarter.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a follow-up if I can would be whether -- maybe it's this. Would you be concerned that the better bookings rate you're seeing now, that's leading to the what are in a sense better than seasonal guidance, could be a head fake if oil stays at below  $30 a
componenttext: So a follow-up if I can would be whether -- maybe it's this. Would you be concerned that the better bookings rate you're seeing now, that's leading to the what are in a sense better than seasonal guidance, could be a head fake if oil stays at below  $30 a barrel that continues to pressure the whole sort of industrial complex?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a hard call to say, but if you ask me my opinion, my sense is that, that headwind we've already faced. I think we've had these relatively low prices for quite a while now, and I think most of the customers that have exposure to that market have pro
componenttext: That's a hard call to say, but if you ask me my opinion, my sense is that, that headwind we've already faced. I think we've had these relatively low prices for quite a while now, and I think most of the customers that have exposure to that market have probably reacted already.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess so. All I wanted to add was that although we're seeing strong bookings at the beginning of this year, at the beginning of this quarter, I mean, we are still bothered by the lack of any real good macroeconomic news. And so I don't know if it's
componenttext: Yes, I guess so. All I wanted to add was that although we're seeing strong bookings at the beginning of this year, at the beginning of this quarter, I mean, we are still bothered by the lack of any real good macroeconomic news. And so I don't know if it's a head fake but we have to be mindful of that.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if you kind of take a longer view, low-priced petroleum is probably in the long term a pretty good thing. So even there might be some near-term pain, I think long term, this is going to be a positive.
componenttext: And if you kind of take a longer view, low-priced petroleum is probably in the long term a pretty good thing. So even there might be some near-term pain, I think long term, this is going to be a positive.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll now take a question from Chris Caso from Susquehanna Financial Group.
componenttext: And we'll now take a question from Chris Caso from Susquehanna Financial Group.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm just wondering if you could provide just some commentary. I understand what you're seeing with the bookings itself. Maybe if you have some color about the customers themselves, what they're telling you, and you guys are in Hong Kong right now. I'm sur
componenttext: I'm just wondering if you could provide just some commentary. I understand what you're seeing with the bookings itself. Maybe if you have some color about the customers themselves, what they're telling you, and you guys are in Hong Kong right now. I'm sure you're doing some customer meetings right now. Are you getting that feeling from the customers that perhaps they're feeling a little bit better about things now, and perhaps better than what the stock market seems to be suggesting?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there's probably a different approach to the growth that we're seeing. I think if you look at all of our markets, there's 3 of them that the company has focused on for a while: the automotive, the industrial and the communications market. And the
componenttext: I think there's probably a different approach to the growth that we're seeing. I think if you look at all of our markets, there's 3 of them that the company has focused on for a while: the automotive, the industrial and the communications market. And the bookings in those -- all 3 of those markets have picked up and those are really the markets that are driving our growth. And I think what we're seeing is the fact that we've concentrated our sales efforts, our product design efforts in really the markets, the analog markets that are growing. And I think that's what's helping us. I think it's less of some customers doing a great job or some market is doing well, I think we've picked the right markets and we've been at it now for quite a while. And we're seeing the benefits of it.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and as a follow on, if you could talk a bit about, a little more color on what you were talking about with respect to inventory levels. I mean, it sounds like your customers were burning through inventory toward the end of last year, and perhaps som
componenttext: Okay, and as a follow on, if you could talk a bit about, a little more color on what you were talking about with respect to inventory levels. I mean, it sounds like your customers were burning through inventory toward the end of last year, and perhaps some of the improvement you're seeing now is, I guess, the resumption of orders from some customers who were burning through inventory?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that we are closer. And I think this question was asked in a similar way before. I think we're -- we feel like we're shipping to demand right now.  We burned off the inventory layer that arose once the end customer demand declined. And so cus
componenttext: Yes, I think that we are closer. And I think this question was asked in a similar way before. I think we're -- we feel like we're shipping to demand right now.  We burned off the inventory layer that arose once the end customer demand declined. And so customers sort of took the layer down their safety stock that was -- they're expecting higher run rate so I think we burned through that and we're shipping to actual end-customer demand, more or less. We think any type of major inventory correction is behind us.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: But the customers' targets for inventory haven't changed. At this point they're getting back to normal inventory levels, not raising those targets at this point?
componenttext: But the customers' targets for inventory haven't changed. At this point they're getting back to normal inventory levels, not raising those targets at this point?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I don't think what we're seeing now is they've taken inventory down and now they're adding it back. I mean, they've taken it down and now they are ordering to meet the actual demand. And so I would expect, if demand picks up as we see from beginni
componenttext: I mean, I don't think what we're seeing now is they've taken inventory down and now they're adding it back. I mean, they've taken it down and now they are ordering to meet the actual demand. And so I would expect, if demand picks up as we see from beginning part of the quarter, if that was to continue, eventually some of that inventory has to be built back up. But I don't think that's going on right now.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the inventory situation at the customers are still pretty lean. And we kind of normally think of the December month as being a pretty quiet month. And we actually saw some significant expedite activities from our customers where they don't ex
componenttext: Yes, I think the inventory situation at the customers are still pretty lean. And we kind of normally think of the December month as being a pretty quiet month. And we actually saw some significant expedite activities from our customers where they don't expedite us unless either, 1, they get surprised with an order, or 2, that they've run their inventory so low that they need some extra help from us. So that was kind of a positive feel is that customers are having to expedite us for product.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think in general, our customers are as confused as a lot of suppliers. They're trying to figure out which way business is moving.
componenttext: I think in general, our customers are as confused as a lot of suppliers. They're trying to figure out which way business is moving.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll now take a question from Ross Seymore from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And we'll now take a question from Ross Seymore from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess one area that hasn't been asked about thus far is the communication infrastructure side. You just mentioned it's one of your 3 focus areas. I realize it stayed unchanged as a percentage of bookings, but can you talk a little bit about what you're
componenttext: I guess one area that hasn't been asked about thus far is the communication infrastructure side. You just mentioned it's one of your 3 focus areas. I realize it stayed unchanged as a percentage of bookings, but can you talk a little bit about what you're seeing there from the wireline versus wireless side and maybe any geographic color as well?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's -- this market is kind of fits and starts. It's staying the same as a percentage but it did obviously grow in absolute dollars. And for us, the part of the communications market, particularly when you look towards the wireless portion, isn't in
componenttext: Yes, it's -- this market is kind of fits and starts. It's staying the same as a percentage but it did obviously grow in absolute dollars. And for us, the part of the communications market, particularly when you look towards the wireless portion, isn't in the base station type of area. Really, the sort of non-wired or non-wireless portion is really where the growth that we are seeing. Sort of the networking -- optical is coming back to life. We were seeing as these optical applications go from 40G to 100G, to 200G to 400G. There is some really tough problems that our customers need to solve. And that particular part of the market looks pretty good. There's some performance issues, there's some very tight space constraints that they have to deal with. And so the sort of optical part of the business looks pretty decent.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess as my follow-up, just getting to the nearer-term in the March quarter, can you give us a rough idea of the turns assumption that you guys have for the March quarter this year and how that compares to maybe the December quarter? And if it's a more
componenttext: I guess as my follow-up, just getting to the nearer-term in the March quarter, can you give us a rough idea of the turns assumption that you guys have for the March quarter this year and how that compares to maybe the December quarter? And if it's a more meaningful comparison to the March quarter of last year? And what the actual turns were?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Boy, to be honest, I don't even remember what the turns was last year, but I know that the turns that we expect this quarter, probably in the 60% range, which is sort of normal. We shouldn't really -- with the kind of bookings that we expect on this kind
componenttext: Boy, to be honest, I don't even remember what the turns was last year, but I know that the turns that we expect this quarter, probably in the 60% range, which is sort of normal. We shouldn't really -- with the kind of bookings that we expect on this kind of strength which we're counting on, it shouldn't be a problem, but again, we'll have to see what happens with bookings, ultimately.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from C.J. Muse from ISI Group.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from C.J. Muse from ISI Group.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, getting back to the seasonal guide in this macro uncertainty, just curious if you can talk a little bit about whether you think this is leveraged to the right sub segments in terms of end markets whether rising content and/or a la higher ASPs as
componenttext: I guess, getting back to the seasonal guide in this macro uncertainty, just curious if you can talk a little bit about whether you think this is leveraged to the right sub segments in terms of end markets whether rising content and/or a la higher ASPs as you alluded to? Would love to hear just color on that front.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Honestly, I don't understand what you're asking for. I mean, could you repeat that so I would maybe get another...
componenttext: Honestly, I don't understand what you're asking for. I mean, could you repeat that so I would maybe get another...

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. Trying to balance seasonal guide with macro uncertainty and there, just wondering, are you just leveraged simply to the right sub end markets that you've been attacking over the last couple of years? Is it a rising  content story for you? Is it
componenttext: Yes, sure. Trying to balance seasonal guide with macro uncertainty and there, just wondering, are you just leveraged simply to the right sub end markets that you've been attacking over the last couple of years? Is it a rising  content story for you? Is it a rising ASP? Really trying to better understand the drivers there.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think you hit it on the head, is that, it's -- there are headwinds, obviously, that are out there, but I think we've, either through good fortune, luck, or brilliance had picked the right markets to go after. And even though there are some economic
componenttext: Yes, I think you hit it on the head, is that, it's -- there are headwinds, obviously, that are out there, but I think we've, either through good fortune, luck, or brilliance had picked the right markets to go after. And even though there are some economic headwinds, the content in the automotive market, which has been our fastest growing end market, just has accelerated and will probably continue to accelerate for quite a while. So I think we're seeing some growth here, partially because of seasonality. But I think, at least as  important is the fact that our products and our sales efforts and our design efforts are in the markets that seem to be doing relatively well. I say this all the time, and it surprises people, is the -- if you look at the total analog market, the industrial and the automotives make up 50% of the total analog market. Not us, but the total analog market. And we -- that's where the majority of our business is directed towards. So we're kind of focused really in the growth areas of the analog market and we seem to be doing pretty well right now.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And I guess, as a quick follow-up, can you walk through the moving parts again in terms of what we should be expecting for gross margin in terms of mix, ASP, FX?
componenttext: That's helpful. And I guess, as a quick follow-up, can you walk through the moving parts again in terms of what we should be expecting for gross margin in terms of mix, ASP, FX?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: As I stated in the opening commentary, quite honestly, that to get a 60 base improvement on a little over $5 million increase in sales is unusual. So there is a lot of moving parts in there. So it's difficult to say going forward, which of those parts wil
componenttext: As I stated in the opening commentary, quite honestly, that to get a 60 base improvement on a little over $5 million increase in sales is unusual. So there is a lot of moving parts in there. So it's difficult to say going forward, which of those parts will continue. I do know for sure that there is a slight headwind if you can call it that, just that we know we are closing down our back-end factory and so less production days means some inefficiencies, less absorption. So that affects us.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It includes the effect of the Chinese New Year.
componenttext: It includes the effect of the Chinese New Year.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the Chinese New Year on Singapore and in Malaysia. But the ASP certainly helps and that's mixed. But I can't say what just yet what mix is going to be in the current quarter. I will say that in fairness to our factories, it wasn't just number of prod
componenttext: Yes, the Chinese New Year on Singapore and in Malaysia. But the ASP certainly helps and that's mixed. But I can't say what just yet what mix is going to be in the current quarter. I will say that in fairness to our factories, it wasn't just number of production days, I mean, there's some real P&L improvement and some cost-saving efforts that they've achieved. But in terms of color going forward, I do expect -- I don't expect another 60 base improvement in gross margin on  higher sales growth if we actually hit our target. So I'm a little cautious about saying that. I wouldn't expect even with the shutdown of our back-end factories for Chinese New Year,  I wouldn't expect it to decline. Hopefully we'll get some improvement but it's too early to know. Just like you said, there's just a lot of moving pieces.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we will now take our next question from Craig Ellis from B. Riley.
componenttext: And we will now take our next question from Craig Ellis from B. Riley.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first is just a follow-up on your comments, Lothar, around the automotive business. I just want to ensure I'm understanding how your business is evolving. Are you saying that content growth is accelerating because we're starting to see some of the mor
componenttext: The first is just a follow-up on your comments, Lothar, around the automotive business. I just want to ensure I'm understanding how your business is evolving. Are you saying that content growth is accelerating because we're starting to see some of the more advanced systems in traditional automobiles. Or is content growth accelerating for Linear Tech because as the TAM expands to include things like buses and other mass transit type systems, you've just got a blended content growth rate that's better than what it's been recently?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it is a little bit of both. And clearly, you spin back time 10 years ago, there wasn't a lot of electronics. There was the NAV and the entertainment systems and that's where really most of the electronics was concentrated in a car. Now you've got
componenttext: I think it is a little bit of both. And clearly, you spin back time 10 years ago, there wasn't a lot of electronics. There was the NAV and the entertainment systems and that's where really most of the electronics was concentrated in a car. Now you've got all sorts of drive-by wires, you got LED lighting, you've got BMS, you got hybrid and electric cars and that's because we work with the car companies and we already know model year of '17, '18, '19 what sort of electronic content they're going to have. And there's just a tremendous amount of new opportunities. Things like 48-volt battery systems, they're coming. They're -- I think there's already model year '16, '17, there's a couple of car companies that will have 48-volt battery systems. And then that just opens up a whole new area. And I think what  probably helps us a lot as well is the fact that there's been some geographies, particularly China, that's pushing very hard on alternatively-fueled vehicles.  And so it's just -- and we talked about this ADAS stuff that's coming. And so it's really just a lot of new opportunities for electronics that's really helping us in the automotive market. And you asked me if it's accelerating. I think to some extent, probably is. I mean, we can see opportunity upon opportunity in that market.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The follow-up, Don, nice $0.02 dividend increase -- the second consecutive multi-penny increase for the company. Where are we with respect to an optimal level, as a percent of free cash flow, for your dividend payment now?
componenttext: The follow-up, Don, nice $0.02 dividend increase -- the second consecutive multi-penny increase for the company. Where are we with respect to an optimal level, as a percent of free cash flow, for your dividend payment now?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: An optimal level for our cash flow? Well, I think what we've said is, to be honest, it's -- we don't have an optimal level of cash flow. I mean, we think that the increase in the dividend year in and year out is sort of our first commitment to our shareho
componenttext: An optimal level for our cash flow? Well, I think what we've said is, to be honest, it's -- we don't have an optimal level of cash flow. I mean, we think that the increase in the dividend year in and year out is sort of our first commitment to our shareholders in the return of that capital. We've done that every year since we've commenced it. And then secondarily, at a minimum, we try to retire the shares that are issued to employees. But first and foremost is the dividend, and absent something unforeseen, we expect to increase that every year as long as we can. It's not based upon some optimal level of cash flow.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll now go to Harlan Sur from JPMorgan.
componenttext: And we'll now go to Harlan Sur from JPMorgan.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: In your prepared remarks, you mentioned  seeing positive demand signs in certain geos and end markets this quarter. I know it's early days for the team but can you just give us a bit more color on what areas and geos  have seen the positive demand pull th
componenttext: In your prepared remarks, you mentioned  seeing positive demand signs in certain geos and end markets this quarter. I know it's early days for the team but can you just give us a bit more color on what areas and geos  have seen the positive demand pull this quarter? I know industrial and auto are typically stronger but any color would be great.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, I think, certainly, Asia Pacific is showing strength. We talked about China, but Korea is doing pretty well. Europe is a little weak but we see some signs there. Japan, we already talked about is, it's somewhat weak and being affected by Chi
componenttext: Well, I mean, I think, certainly, Asia Pacific is showing strength. We talked about China, but Korea is doing pretty well. Europe is a little weak but we see some signs there. Japan, we already talked about is, it's somewhat weak and being affected by China. Then within Europe, I said Europe is sort of holding its own, it's not strong but it's not real weak either, but within Europe, there's different countries that are affected. I think Germany is being affected a little bit by China as well, so Germany, obviously, a big piece of Europe, but I think they are a little weak right now but I wouldn't say very weak. So it's -- we're still broad-based  so it's difficult to say which country, but I -- it looks like we're showing a little bit of strength in general, we'll just have to see if that continues.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then were there any differences in bookings momentum between your disti and OEM customers in December? And what are the trends that you're seeing OEM versus disti this quarter?
componenttext: Great. And then were there any differences in bookings momentum between your disti and OEM customers in December? And what are the trends that you're seeing OEM versus disti this quarter?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually I think between OEM and disti, OEM actually bounced back a little better than distribution. Distribution was somewhat flattish to maybe down a little bit. But nothing inordinate. We would hope that just like the rest of our internal business, our
componenttext: Actually I think between OEM and disti, OEM actually bounced back a little better than distribution. Distribution was somewhat flattish to maybe down a little bit. But nothing inordinate. We would hope that just like the rest of our internal business, our direct business, that distribution will grow along with us.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I will now take a question from Steve Smigie from Raymond James.
componenttext: I will now take a question from Steve Smigie from Raymond James.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to touch a little bit more on China industrial. You mentioned some strength there. Obviously, it's broad-based.  Are there a couple of markets of strength there that's doing a little bit better? Is it factory automation, for example, and is
componenttext: I just wanted to touch a little bit more on China industrial. You mentioned some strength there. Obviously, it's broad-based.  Are there a couple of markets of strength there that's doing a little bit better? Is it factory automation, for example, and is that strength more around their units are starting to do a bit better again? Or is it you guys are just again getting a lot of dollar content on  boxes?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, that's an area that is pretty hard to pin down because it's so broad, there's so many different customers, they buy such a diverse bill of materials. But from -- we're here in Asia right now, and with discussions with the sales team, you kind of hi
componenttext: Again, that's an area that is pretty hard to pin down because it's so broad, there's so many different customers, they buy such a diverse bill of materials. But from -- we're here in Asia right now, and with discussions with the sales team, you kind of hit it on the head, some of the interesting areas in industrial, which maybe isn't helping exactly right now, but may in the near future is the sort of automation area. There's a lot of talk about it here. We see customer interest in that area. And so that may be something that's interesting going forward, for LTC.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And just my follow-up question was around inventory. You talked about that getting cleaned up. Can you help us understand a little bit in terms of that cleanup, is it more cleanup on the channel side, the distributors or is it OEM? And on the
componenttext: Okay, great. And just my follow-up question was around inventory. You talked about that getting cleaned up. Can you help us understand a little bit in terms of that cleanup, is it more cleanup on the channel side, the distributors or is it OEM? And on the channel side, where did you see the biggest change? Is it the big Arrow, Avnets out there? Or is it local Chinese guys where you've seen the change?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, to be honest, I don't think I have that information nor do I recall the distribution inventory by region. But in terms of when the inventory had to come down because demand fell, I think there was inventory correction that affected OEM and distributio
componenttext: No, to be honest, I don't think I have that information nor do I recall the distribution inventory by region. But in terms of when the inventory had to come down because demand fell, I think there was inventory correction that affected OEM and distribution equally. It had to be done on both channels. But in terms of what part of the channel, where it was greater and now it's bounced back, I honestly don't know. I don't have the information broken down like that.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We will now take a question from Vivek Arya from Bank of America.
componenttext: We will now take a question from Vivek Arya from Bank of America.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's a lot of concern about just currency devaluation in China, and just FX fluctuations. I realize the semiconductor companies usually price in dollars. But I'm wondering if it's having any direct or indirect impact on your business? And does it even
componenttext: There's a lot of concern about just currency devaluation in China, and just FX fluctuations. I realize the semiconductor companies usually price in dollars. But I'm wondering if it's having any direct or indirect impact on your business? And does it even come up in discussions with your OEM or distributor customers?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think I've answered this question before in the past. We're not going to say it has no effect. Like you said, we're a U.S. dollar company, our competitors also price in U.S. dollars. It certainly has some effect. You mentioned specifically China, and I
componenttext: I think I've answered this question before in the past. We're not going to say it has no effect. Like you said, we're a U.S. dollar company, our competitors also price in U.S. dollars. It certainly has some effect. You mentioned specifically China, and I don't ever remember it coming up in an internal conversation about price, foreign currency issues resulting from China; I know that for sure. But just in general, does the movement of foreign currencies  have some pick -- some effect on our revenues? I'm sure the answer to that is yes, but it's never been great, whether the dollar is strong or whether the dollar is weak. It's probably little, but I wouldn't say it's significant in either direction.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as a quick follow-up, you have a very strong balance sheet, over $1.3 billion in cash. Does this current environment make you think more about either doing more buybacks or thinking about any other M&A in the industry? Or do you think just caution in
componenttext: And as a quick follow-up, you have a very strong balance sheet, over $1.3 billion in cash. Does this current environment make you think more about either doing more buybacks or thinking about any other M&A in the industry? Or do you think just caution in the environment makes you not think about those things more actively?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mentioned M&A. We're not a big player in that field. And so when we -- in the past, we did a large transaction in 2007, when we felt our strategy was not well understood and that's when we were focusing more on automotive and industrial. We retired th
componenttext: You mentioned M&A. We're not a big player in that field. And so when we -- in the past, we did a large transaction in 2007, when we felt our strategy was not well understood and that's when we were focusing more on automotive and industrial. We retired that debt a little over a year ago. We've been using our existing cash to retire shares, and we've done that. We bought back at least those that we've issued. That's sort of our secondary cause, if you will, behind the dividend. But it's -- in terms of something going forward, we'll have to just wait and see.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016

componenttext: And we'll now take a question from Stephen Chin from UBS.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: First one is on your automotive business. I just wanted to see if you can help parse out a little bit more of some of the exposures in that business? When you look across the whole product line, can you break out the relative exposure between gasoline car
componenttext: First one is on your automotive business. I just wanted to see if you can help parse out a little bit more of some of the exposures in that business? When you look across the whole product line, can you break out the relative exposure between gasoline cars versus also alternative energy cars like hybrids and electrics if that's possible? And also just with the long sort of design win visibility you have, and where you're approximately going to? Any sense for whether your products are still mainly concentrated in sort of high to mid-end vehicles? Or are you seeing your products migrate down towards mid and then -- and also mass market vehicles as well?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Initially, when we started to see a pickup in the automotive business, it was really dominated by conventional gasoline-powered cars. That is starting to evolve and it's -- as more car OEMs field electric and hybrid and plug-in hybrid cars, even though to
componenttext: Initially, when we started to see a pickup in the automotive business, it was really dominated by conventional gasoline-powered cars. That is starting to evolve and it's -- as more car OEMs field electric and hybrid and plug-in hybrid cars, even though today, the quantity of those cars is still relatively small, the content of opportunities for Linear are significantly higher -- multiples higher in those types of cars. So the hybrid and electric vehicle market is a very interesting market for us because it has a much, much higher electronic content for us. So that's where we're seeing some pretty significant opportunities. But there's sort of waves of new areas for electronics that are coming into  cars. I mentioned earlier, the 48-volt battery system, that's going to have a wave of opportunities. ADAS systems is going to have a wave of opportunities. And we're just seeing these waves of opportunities coming in, and I think there's just a lot of good opportunities for vehicles right now and we've seen the benefit of it in the last several years where we've seen pretty steady growth in our automotive sales and also in the percentage of our sales that go into the automotive market. So I hope that answered part of your question.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Linear Technology Corporation Fiscal 2016 Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Don Zerio, Vice President of Finance and Chief F
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Linear Technology Corporation Fiscal 2016 Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Don Zerio, Vice President of Finance and Chief Financial Officer. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Welcome to the Linear Technology conference call. I'm joined today by Bob Swanson, our Executive Chairman; and Lothar Maier, our CEO. I would like to remind you that in our presentation today and our answer to certain questions that may foll
componenttext:
Good morning. Welcome to the Linear Technology conference call. I'm joined today by Bob Swanson, our Executive Chairman; and Lothar Maier, our CEO. I would like to remind you that in our presentation today and our answer to certain questions that may follow, we may make forward-looking statements that are dependent on certain risks and uncertainties, including, but not limited to, our financial results for future periods; our ability to produce and sell existing products; the timing of introduction of new products and processes; and general conditions in the world economy and financial markets. In addition to these risks, please refer to the risk factors listed in the company's annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended June 28, 2015 and our subsequent quarterly filings on Form 10-Q. Also SEC Regulation FD regarding selective disclosure influences our interaction with investors. Accordingly, this conference call will be our forum to respond to questions regarding our estimated financial performance going forward. Should you have questions regarding our estimates of sales and profits or other financial matters for the upcoming quarter, this is the time we are free to respond to your questions. 
As noted in our press release, which was released yesterday just after the market closed, revenue for the March quarter came in at the higher end of our guidance at $361.1 million, up 4% from the December quarter. Gross margin increased to 76.2% from 75.7%, benefiting from the higher sales base of full quarter production in our fabs and certain other manufacturing efficiencies. Recall that our second quarter have less production days in our fabs due to holidays and plant shutdown days. Operating margin improved to 45% of sales up from 43.1% due to the higher gross margin and 1 less week of operating expenses as we had 14 weeks in our second quarter. Our effective tax rate was slightly higher in the third quarter at 21.75% versus 19.5% in Q2 on lower discrete quarterly items. Net income and earnings per share were $128.4 million and $0.52 per share. All told, this was a pretty good quarter and we are happy with the results given global macroeconomic that are still providing some headwinds. We beat the midpoint of our guidance, we increased gross margin and operating margin and our bookings increased over the prior quarter at a level that should allow us to grow in the fourth quarter as well. The transportation market continues to grow nicely, and we are seeing recovery in the industrial market and to a lesser extent, the communications market, which has been weak for some time. We are seeing recovery across the broad-based including the distribution and the smaller and midsized customers. In general, inventories in the channel appear to be imbalanced and we believe we are shipping to end customer demand. However, there remains pockets of weaknesses in certain geographies, and the computer market remains particularly weak, though that is not a major market for us. We remain cautious given the general business climate, but based upon our third quarter bookings and our current run rate, we are currently projecting revenue to be up 2% to 5% in the June quarter. 
Turning to bookings by region and market sector, as a reminder, we have posted bookings by market and revenue by geography for the quarter on our website at linear.com under Investor Relations Supplemental Information. We posted this information by the end of our business day on the day we released our results. Total bookings increased for the quarter and we had a positive book-to-bill ratio. Bookings increased to both North America and the international market. Within international, bookings were up in each of our major geographic regions, Europe, Japan and Asia Pacific. We continue to do particularly well in China, as bookings were up the most in that region on the strength of automotive, though our industrial business is growing in that country too. With respect to bookings by market sector, bookings were up in each of our major markets that represent 86% of our business, industrial, transportation and communications, and our smaller markets, military space grew modestly, while computer and consumer showed declines. The computer market, particularly PCs and notebooks, continue to be particularly weak. Industrial continues to be our largest market at 44% of our bookings, up from 43% the previous quarter. Industrial bookings increased in each of our major geographic regions led by North America and Europe. The breadth of this increase across our customer base is giving us some comfort that the noticeable weakness we experienced in this market over the past several months is in recovery, and that the inventory correction that resulted is behind us. We believe we are shipping to end customer demand, and the inventories in the channel and at the OEMs are at least stable, if not lean. 
Turning to transportation bookings, this market continues to show the highest percentage growth and it was 24% of our businesses that quarter, up from 23%. The increase in bookings in transportation was driven primarily by Asia Pacific, but we saw growth in Japan and the U.S. as well. The U.S. has been a smaller transportation market for us, but we are making good strides here, and is up nicely for the quarter in percentage terms and opportunities to continues to increase. Europe bookings were down in transportation modestly in the quarter but coming off a relatively strong Q2. Transportation growth in Asia Pacific continues to be strong, and it was the highest region in total transportation bookings, overtaking both Europe and Japan for the first time. As you should know by now, we have been particularly successful with our parts in the China and Korea market. As I have noticed on previous calls, China is all-in on electric vehicles as one part of the solution for the severe air pollution, offering incentives to both businesses and consumers to build and buy electric vehicles, including autos, taxis and buses. Our superior BMS parts have won a significant business in China where we enjoy very high market share for battery management systems. Our transportation business in this region should continue to grow strongly for the foreseeable feature. 
Communications remained at 18% of our bookings for the quarter, but after 2 quarters of sequential growth, we are hopeful that this market is beginning to show some life. The large base stations and infrastructure piece of this market continues to be weak, but that is no longer a sizable piece of our communications business. We are seeing growth in optical, networking and datacom, which is the area of the market that we focus. This market was strongest for us in the U.S., while Europe was flat and Asia was down slightly. The computer market was 6% of our bookings, down from 7% last quarter with the decrease primarily in North America where the majority of this business is booked. As stated last quarter, this market is down as expected, as it is suffering due to weaker notebook sales and storage devices. This market may continue to decline a bit more for us over the short term as notebook sales continue to decline. But longer term, we expect growth opportunities as we have compelling products in development that address the higher end of this market where innovation and superior functionality are still needed. 
Bookings for military space and harsh environment products increased modestly this quarter and remained at 6% of our business. Military has rebounded slowly from the weakness we experienced in the first quarter, while the space business have been somewhat flat for the past year. We do expect the space business to pick up as satellite launch activity increases. This is predominantly a U.S. market, but we do book some business in Europe. Both regions saw an increase in bookings this quarter. 
Finally, consumer, our smallest end market where we take business opportunistically when functionality and performance still matter, this market decreased to 2% of our business down from 3% last quarter. With regard to our bookings are actually created, 62% [ph] were created internationally, and 38% in North America, the same as last period. 
Moving to sales, sales increased by 4% from the prior quarter and were down 2.9% from the prior year quarter. Geographically, sales were up the most in Europe followed by North America and Asia Pacific, but were down in Japan, which is not unusual as March is typically their fiscal year end. U.S. sales were up for both OEM and distribution where revenue is recognized on sellthrough basis. On a regional basis, North America was 28% of our business, up from 27% last quarter. Europe was up to 21% this quarter from 19% last quarter. Japan declined to 13% of our business down from 15% last quarter and Asia Pacific decreased from 39% to 38% of sales but was up in absolute dollars. 
Turning to the rest of the income statement, gross margin was up from 75.7% to 76.2%. This is a good result particularly since our overseas assembly and test operations have lowered production days due to Chinese New Year. Gross margin was aided by the higher sales base, which reduces fixed overhead per units and an increase in our average selling price to $1.97, up $0.05 from $1.92 last quarter. The fourth quarter is a full production quarter for all of our plants, and we expect to grow sales. So I do expect some margin expansion subject to the product mix within sales. 
R&D decreased $0.2 million sequentially to $62.6 million primarily due to lower labor and fringe cost as there was 1 extra week in the prior quarter. In addition, legal costs were down. Partially offsetting these decreases, vacation cost and profit-sharing increased. Vacation costs were higher as there were no shutdown days and much less vacation taken in the third quarter than during the holiday season. 
SG&A decreased $0.4 million sequentially to $43 million. Similar to R&D, this was mostly due to lower labor and fringe cost from 1 less week in the quarter compared to Q2. In addition, other cost decrease such as advertising, travel and foreign sales cost from foreign exchange. Similar to R&D, these declines were partially offset by higher vacation costs and profit-sharing. 
Operating income increased by $13 million to $162.5 million, representing 45% of our sales. Interest and other income increased slightly to $1.6 million on higher invested cash, net of small loss from foreign currency transactions. Our quarterly effective income tax rate was higher this quarter, at 21.75% versus 19.5% last quarter due to lower quarterly discrete items. Next quarter, option discrete tax items, if any, we expect our annual effective tax rate to be in the 24% to 24.5% range. Net income for the period was $128.4 million, up $6.9 million and was 35.6% of sales up from 35%. The average shares outstanding used in the calculation of earnings per share decreased by 116,000 shares. The weighted average of stock repurchases, both this period and last period, more than offset vesting of employee stock awards.  GAAP earnings per share was $0.52, up from $0.50 in the prior quarter. Without the impact of stock-based compensation of $19.9 million, diluted earnings per share would have been $0.59 per share. 
Looking at just a few major components of our balance sheet, during the current quarter, the company's cash, cash equivalent and marketable securities increased by $55.3 million to $1.36 billion, net of spending $78.2 million of dividends which has been increased to $0.32 per share and spending $32.6 million on stock purchases of approximately 800,000 shares. Capital expenditures for the quarter were $13.2 million. Accounts receivable of $152.9 million increased by $7.8 million on the higher sales base and DSO was 39 days up from 38 days as we had an extra week of collections in the second quarter. Inventory at $94.2 million was essentially flat versus the prior quarter and we believe to be in good profile to support our business and keep lead times relatively short. Our quarterly average inventory terms were ups slightly to 3.7x per year. 
Looking forward, at the current bookings rate, we are guiding revenue to be up 2% to 5% in the June quarter. Three quarters ago, when we announced that revenues for our first fiscal quarter would be down significantly, our expectation was that the sudden drop was more of a short-term correction rather than a deep down cycle. At this point, it appears that our reading of the tea leaves was accurate. Inventories in the channel now appear to be imbalanced, if not lean. We are shipping to end customer demand, bookings have picked up and our largest market, industrial, appears to be in recovery. However, there's still a fragile market. The global macroeconomic climate is not particularly favorable when certain geographies remain weak and GDP of 2% is considered good growth. Nevertheless, we feel good about our strategy and the growth opportunities ahead in the markets where we have focused our resources and product development, particularly in the industrial, transportation and communications markets. These are the markets that will drive the growth in high-performance analog, and the decisions that we made several years ago and executed upon now leave us well-positioned to capitalize. 
I will now open up the conference call to questions to be addressed to Bob, Lothar or me.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of David Wong from Wells Fargo.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you give us attitude to cash on the balance sheet and use of cash, and in particular, what you see in terms of stock repurchases going forward?
componenttext: Can you give us attitude to cash on the balance sheet and use of cash, and in particular, what you see in terms of stock repurchases going forward?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, David, as you know, we retired our convertible note. It's been about 2 years now. And after having debt service for 7 years, we enjoy not having it. So for the time being, we continue to like not having the debt service. We prefer to use our existing
componenttext: Yes, David, as you know, we retired our convertible note. It's been about 2 years now. And after having debt service for 7 years, we enjoy not having it. So for the time being, we continue to like not having the debt service. We prefer to use our existing cash to fund our dividend and stock repurchases. And so for the time period, that position hasn't changed. But it's not that we're necessarily against taking some debt. We've done it in the past. But currently, we've chosen to use our existing cash to fund our stock repurchases.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Craig Hettenbach for Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Craig Hettenbach for Morgan Stanley.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question or comment on China and EVs, just in terms of certainly it's still a small market as a percentage terms, but the dollar content opportunity is much higher. Curious to get your thoughts on just from a design perspective and what you're seei
componenttext: Just a question or comment on China and EVs, just in terms of certainly it's still a small market as a percentage terms, but the dollar content opportunity is much higher. Curious to get your thoughts on just from a design perspective and what you're seeing from customers having influences what you think about the opportunity over the next 1, 2, 3 years?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you think about China, particularly when we talked about is this EV market, it's not just cars, it's taxis and, to a large extent, it's also buses and some machinery. And when we win business on the BMS side, we typically win business around the rest
componenttext: When you think about China, particularly when we talked about is this EV market, it's not just cars, it's taxis and, to a large extent, it's also buses and some machinery. And when we win business on the BMS side, we typically win business around the rest of the car as well. So granted these types of vehicles are so relatively small percentage, the content can be 2x, 3x, 4x, 5x, 10x as much as in the conventional car and the numbers may be were small but appears to be getting quite a bit bigger if you look at how many plug-in and electric cars China produced in 2015, it was around 300,000. And that's going to double, we think, in '16. And right now, with the incentives that the Chinese government has put in place, they don't appear to be an end to this.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, and if I could just follow up just on the topic of BMS, I think, you guys are in your third of your generation of products so just seemingly it is a big opportunity but just the things you're doing on the technology front to make sure that you mai
componenttext: Got it, and if I could just follow up just on the topic of BMS, I think, you guys are in your third of your generation of products so just seemingly it is a big opportunity but just the things you're doing on the technology front to make sure that you maintain kind of a leadership position for these type of products.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and it's interesting because every OEM does it a little bit different. So there isn't like one solution that solves everybody's problems. Some people have efficiency, some people want precision, some customers want communication. And so it's a differ
componenttext: Yes, and it's interesting because every OEM does it a little bit different. So there isn't like one solution that solves everybody's problems. Some people have efficiency, some people want precision, some customers want communication. And so it's a different set of requirements from customer to customer. And so it's just an ever evolving field and it's -- the requirements are, obviously, it's precision. The lithium batteries are very expensive. And so if we can make the measurements more precise, it means they have to purchase less batteries. When your battery system stops working on a vehicle, whether a plug-in or a hybrid, the car stops. So they're looking for things like redundancies and backup systems so it's a pretty complicated product with a lot of different hooks in it, and every different -- every OEM has a different hop button.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ross Seymore from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ross Seymore from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just have a question on the side of the equation, Don, you mentioned benefit of that had a little bit and the gross margin just going to more holistically, think that  $1.97 was up nicely sequentially and year-over-year, but I think it's also the highest
componenttext: Just have a question on the side of the equation, Don, you mentioned benefit of that had a little bit and the gross margin just going to more holistically, think that  $1.97 was up nicely sequentially and year-over-year, but I think it's also the highest we've seen for our company as far as I can find in history. Can you just talk a little bit about what is driving ASPs up for your company over time, and if in a single quarter there was any particularly unique movements.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think just in general, the strategy change that we made years ago as you know to the focus on the consumer and more towards industrial and transportation and communications, just over the last several years, that strategy in and of itself helped our ASP
componenttext: I think just in general, the strategy change that we made years ago as you know to the focus on the consumer and more towards industrial and transportation and communications, just over the last several years, that strategy in and of itself helped our ASP and it did. And you also know, we have good success in our module business which continues to grow quite frankly, beyond our expectations and not to know the great product that we continue to see just running. And the ASP on the modules is quite high, and we're also talking today about our success with battery management systems, which also is a relatively high ASP product. So our strategy in general and the success of certain of our products is continuing to drive ASP higher, and it certainly wouldn't surprise us if we got over $2.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, just to highlight, we used to have ASPs even greater than $2 for a prolonged period of time. We'd have to go back about 15 years to see that. And as we entered into the consumer business, we saw our ASPs drop. I think the low quarter for us was like
componenttext: Yes, just to highlight, we used to have ASPs even greater than $2 for a prolonged period of time. We'd have to go back about 15 years to see that. And as we entered into the consumer business, we saw our ASPs drop. I think the low quarter for us was like $1.38. And then we've seen a steady growth back to what we think is probably likely for us is to get above $2 here in the future. And we feel that way for the reasons that Don said. We've got this BMS products, we have module products. And if you look at virtually everything that we've got in the design pipeline are really products that should warrant prices above $2.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, I guess as my follow up, just switching gears to the industrial side, it's good to see it is acting better and you gave a lot of color on that. I guess if we can just compare it to a year ago at this time, it looks like your revenues are in the sam
componenttext: Great, I guess as my follow up, just switching gears to the industrial side, it's good to see it is acting better and you gave a lot of color on that. I guess if we can just compare it to a year ago at this time, it looks like your revenues are in the same ballpark for what you reported in the March quarter and seemingly what you're guiding for that subsegment in June. Could you just compare and contrast what gives you the confidence and how you're feeling about that at the same level of revenues today versus a year ago, when of course, we're on the precipice of that correction short-lived, but correction on the less on the September quarter.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, prior to that correction, we were on a pretty good March in terms of improvements in our industrial business. And I think we had a correction for, quite frankly, reasons I don't fully understand because we didn't lose any customers, we didn't
componenttext: Yes, I mean, prior to that correction, we were on a pretty good March in terms of improvements in our industrial business. And I think we had a correction for, quite frankly, reasons I don't fully understand because we didn't lose any customers, we didn't lose any business. And so I think what we're seeing now is that industrial business, roughly a year ago was doing pretty good for us, resetting and taking off where we were about a year ago.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Tore Svanberg from Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Tore Svanberg from Stifel.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Evan Wang calling in for Tore Svanberg. First question is on the communications. You haven't talked about it potentially being on rebound, I was wondering if you could characterize this a little bit based on maybe the bookings from the first coupl
componenttext: This is Evan Wang calling in for Tore Svanberg. First question is on the communications. You haven't talked about it potentially being on rebound, I was wondering if you could characterize this a little bit based on maybe the bookings from the first couple of weeks so far at this quarter as to the steepness of this recovery. And going forward, even out a couple of quarters if you could.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's -- any of our markets really don't get driven by what's happened in the first few weeks of a quarter. These things evolve literally over years. And we've seen some stress on our communications business because historically, it was roughly evenl
componenttext: Well, it's -- any of our markets really don't get driven by what's happened in the first few weeks of a quarter. These things evolve literally over years. And we've seen some stress on our communications business because historically, it was roughly evenly split between the base station and the networking part of the business. And over the years, what we've been seeing is the base station which have become somewhat commodisized, that business declining and the rest of the business and sort of the networking and infrastructure part of the business improving. And so I think what we're seeing now is the fact that we've given up most of the base station business. We don't have a lot of base station business to lose anymore and what we're seeing is just the pickup of the networking business, which we've been seeing really for years and that's becoming a little bit conspicuous now. There are also some segments in the networking business that are doing well. Don mentioned the optical business. Wherever there's a lot of innovation, it's typically where Linear does well. And the optical markets going between 10G to 20G to 40G, to 100 to 200, 400G. As that progression goes, there's a lot of technology involved. And when that happens, that's good for us. For us, the optical market right now, is doing quite well.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, my follow-up question is for the longer term, you cited that the macro remains weak. And given the strength in your focus markets, is this still a major concern for you, or do you see the strength in these markets sufficient to fuel your growth?
componenttext: Great, my follow-up question is for the longer term, you cited that the macro remains weak. And given the strength in your focus markets, is this still a major concern for you, or do you see the strength in these markets sufficient to fuel your growth?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's an issue for us. We really like to see some strong global GDP growth. So it's an obvious headwind to us, but at the moment, I think we've got enough good products and good markets that we can buck that headwind, to some extent. But quite frankly, we
componenttext: It's an issue for us. We really like to see some strong global GDP growth. So it's an obvious headwind to us, but at the moment, I think we've got enough good products and good markets that we can buck that headwind, to some extent. But quite frankly, we have a lot stronger business if we weren't facing headwind like that.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know, I mentioned Japan. Japan's weak. I mean there was definitely some seasonality with Japan this past quarter. As I mentioned, March is typically their fiscal year and so they would take less delivery and such. But I think there's some real weaknes
componenttext: You know, I mentioned Japan. Japan's weak. I mean there was definitely some seasonality with Japan this past quarter. As I mentioned, March is typically their fiscal year and so they would take less delivery and such. But I think there's some real weakness in Japan. I think they may be affected by China somewhat, but they're still, like we said, there are still pockets of weakness out there. There's not many reasons around the world if at all that are experience any kind of growth, something 3% or better. You can see that, and like I said, 2% is considered strong. So certainly not a great market out there, but I think in the markets that we focused, we're certainly holding our own and we can't use the macroeconomic environment as an excuse. We have to continue to grow, and we think we can do that.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of John Pitzer with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of John Pitzer with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Don, in your prepared comments, you talked about your expectation for the June quarter for there to be additional gross margin leverage based upon sort of fixed cost absorption, maybe offset by mix. Can you help us quantify how much we should see for the
componenttext: Don, in your prepared comments, you talked about your expectation for the June quarter for there to be additional gross margin leverage based upon sort of fixed cost absorption, maybe offset by mix. Can you help us quantify how much we should see for the June quarter? Is this a similar incremental margin that we've seen in March? And then on a similar vein, if you look at where gross margin are today, and I always feel silly asking this question, you're still above 200 basis points of upside to where margins were kind of back in that 2010 time period, around 78%. Is there anything structurally different about the business today that shouldn't allow you, at some point, get back to that margin profile?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know, John, you have to remember where we were in the market back in 2010. I mean, that was a snapback from the 2008, 2009 credit crisis and recession, and so the whole market was, if you recall, was sort of pedal to the metal. Our factory utilization
componenttext: You know, John, you have to remember where we were in the market back in 2010. I mean, that was a snapback from the 2008, 2009 credit crisis and recession, and so the whole market was, if you recall, was sort of pedal to the metal. Our factory utilization at that time was very high. We still had some consumer products that were lower ASP, but also lower cost. That helped get to that very high gross margin. Not that we can't get back there, but that's sort of the perfect environment to get back to a gross margin that in excess of 78%. So I think that's different and you have to look at what that environment is. And secondly, there is some cost to the automotive market, the quality and the reliability that is expected. So, yes, there's higher ASPs there, but the cost, depending upon which product you're talking about, has quite high test costs. So there's that as well. But even on a slightly lower gross margin, the gross margin per unit is higher. So we'll make that trade off everyday. So there's -- i mean there's just a lot of variabilities that go into gross margin which is why I can't necessarily give you a target for what our gross margin is going to be next quarter. I don't know what the mix is going to be yet, I'm not exactly sure what our capacity level will be in the factory. All I can say is, say, look, we just grew about $13 million and added half of 0.50 basis points. I don't know I can promise another 50 basis points but assuming we grow, assuming we have a relatively sort of constant kind of a mix on our products. I would expect to that we would be able to add to gross margin in total, whether it's 20 basis points or 30 basis points or even higher, I can't say right now.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then Lothar, my follow-up is a question around growth. I understand the compares is probably not there because there's been a lot of repositioning in the company. But if you look at the top line growth, since 2010, to the end of this year, it's been s
componenttext: And then Lothar, my follow-up is a question around growth. I understand the compares is probably not there because there's been a lot of repositioning in the company. But if you look at the top line growth, since 2010, to the end of this year, it's been sort of flattish and I can a lot of repositioning within that 5-year period. I'm kind of curious as to how you think we should think about given the repositioning and the focus of the company and then markets. And if not an absolute basis, relative to where the [indiscernible] market is growing, how much faster do you think you can grow on an ongoing basis?

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think you got a pretty good observation there, that 2010, as Don said earlier, was kind of a peak. There was a huge downturn and there was a huge correction and then corrected again after that correction. And if you look back in the last several ye
componenttext: Yes, I think you got a pretty good observation there, that 2010, as Don said earlier, was kind of a peak. There was a huge downturn and there was a huge correction and then corrected again after that correction. And if you look back in the last several years, we've seen steady but modest growth, and I think we need 2 things. One is we need the overall market to get better. And so if we're going to get back to what we always say we'd like to grow or we think we are entitled to grow is 10%, we got to get some decent GDP growth. If you look at our company from where we're positioned, from a product standpoint, from an end market standpoint, we couldn't be any better-positioned than we are presently. So I'm not worried at all about the things that are in our control because I think we've managed that pretty well. We just need a little bit of help from the market and there's no reason why we can't grow 8% or 10% in a year. I doubt -- we do not have a product or market issue.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, let me just follow up on that. If you go back to 2014, we had about 5, if not 6, quarters in a row, where year-over-year, we were growing in a high single-digit, 9%, 10%. That's what we thought we could do and we thought we could continue to do it w
componenttext: John, let me just follow up on that. If you go back to 2014, we had about 5, if not 6, quarters in a row, where year-over-year, we were growing in a high single-digit, 9%, 10%. That's what we thought we could do and we thought we could continue to do it when most of the consumer transition was behind us. So all the new business and new opportunities we now felt after several years of replacing business is now additive on top. So we were sort of there and obviously, after 2014, we fell off that pace as certainly the rest of the market as well. But computer got weak, communications got weak, industrial got weak on us. So again, there's some macroeconomic headwinds. But to Lothar's point, with a little bit more stability and a little bit more growth on average around the globe, we think we can grow back up at that 10% range. And we think we've already shown we can do it. We just need some help for the market.

headline: Linear Technology Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of C.J. Muse with ISI Group.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of C.J. Muse with ISI Group.

componenttext: I guess, first question, when you think about consumer now when we had only a roughly $28 million run rate, clearly much more leveraged to your 3 core businesses. How should we think about normal seasonality patterns in this low growth environment coupled with that mix shift?
